ABMD.description: Adds a ratchet-and-pawl like restraint on one or more variables.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the forces due to the bias should be calculated

MIN.description: Array of starting values for the bias (set rho_m(t), otherwise it is set using the current value of ARG)

NOISE.description: Array of white noise intensities (add a temperature to the ABMD)

SEED.description: Array of seeds for the white noise (add a temperature to the ABMD)

bias.description: the instantaneous value of the bias potential

force2.description: the instantaneous value of the squared force due to this bias potential

_min.description: one or multiple instances of this quantity can be referenced elsewhere in the input file

ABMD.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act 
                     TO - The array of target values 
                  KAPPA - The array of force constants. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                    MIN - Array of starting values for the bias (set rho_m(t), 
                          otherwise it is set using the current value of ARG) 
                  NOISE - Array of white noise intensities (add a temperature to the 
                          ABMD) 
                   SEED - Array of seeds for the white noise (add a temperature to 
                          the ABMD)

ACCUMULATE.description: Sum the elements of this value over the course of the trajectory

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

UPDATE_FROM.description: Only update this action from this time

UPDATE_UNTIL.description: Only update this action until this time

ARG.description: the label of the argument that is being added to on each timestep

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the data should be collected and added to the quantity being averaged

CLEAR.description: the frequency with which to clear all the accumulated data

value.description: a sum calculated from the time series of the input quantity

ACCUMULATE.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the label of the argument that is being added to on each 
                          timestep 
                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which the data should be 
                          collected and added to the quantity being averaged 
                  CLEAR - ( default=0 ) the frequency with which to clear all the 
                          accumulated data. The default value of 0 implies that all the data will 
                          be used and that the grid will never be cleared 
            UPDATE_FROM - Only update this action from this time 
           UPDATE_UNTIL - Only update this action until this time

ADAPTIVE_PATH.description: Compute path collective variables that adapt to the lowest free energy path connecting states A and B.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

REFERENCE.description: a pdb file containing the set of reference configurations

TYPE.description: the manner in which distances are calculated

ARG.description: the list of arguments you would like to use in your definition of the path

COEFFICIENTS.description: the coefficients of the displacements along each argument that should be used when calculating the euclidean distance

NOSPATH.description: do not calculate the spath CV

NOZPATH.description: do not calculate the zpath CV

PROPERTY.description: read in path coordinates by finding option with this label in remark of pdb frames

FIXED.description: the positions in the list of input frames of the two path nodes whose positions remain fixed during the path optimization

HALFLIFE.description: the number of MD steps after which a previously measured path distance weighs only 50 percent in the average

UPDATE.description: the frequency with which the path should be updated

TOLERANCE.description: the tolerance to use for the path updating algorithm that makes all frames equidistant

WFILE.description: file on which to write out the path

FMT.description: the format to use for output files

WSTRIDE.description: frequency with which to write out the path

value.description: the position along and from the adaptive path

ADAPTIVE_PATH.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

              REFERENCE - a pdb file containing the set of reference configurations 
                   TYPE - ( default=OPTIMAL-FAST ) the manner in which distances are 
                          calculated. More information on the different metrics that are 
                          available in PLUMED can be found in the section of the manual on ef 
                          dists 
                  FIXED - the positions in the list of input frames of the two path 
                          nodes whose positions remain fixed during the path optimization 
               HALFLIFE - ( default=-1 ) the number of MD steps after which a 
                          previously measured path distance weighs only 50 percent in the 
                          average. This option may increase convergence by allowing to forget 
                          the memory of a bad initial guess path. The default is to set 
                          this to infinity 
                 UPDATE - the frequency with which the path should be updated 
              TOLERANCE - ( default=1E-6 ) the tolerance to use for the path updating 
                          algorithm that makes all frames equidistant 
                    FMT - ( default=%f ) the format to use for output files 
                WSTRIDE - ( default=0, ) frequency with which to write out the path 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                NOSPATH - ( default=off ) do not calculate the spath CV 
                NOZPATH - ( default=off ) do not calculate the zpath CV 
                  GPATH - ( default=off ) calculate the trigonometric path 
                    ARG - the list of arguments you would like to use in your 
                          definition of the path 
           COEFFICIENTS - the coefficients of the displacements along each argument 
                          that should be used when calculating the euclidean distance 
               PROPERTY - read in path coordinates by finding option with this label 
                          in remark of pdb frames 
                  WFILE - file on which to write out the path

ALPHABETA.description: Measures a distance including pbc between the instantaneous values of a set of torsional angles and set of reference values.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

ATOMS.description: the atoms involved for each of the torsions you wish to calculate

REFERENCE.description: the reference values for each of the torsional angles

COEFFICIENT.description: the coefficient for each of the torsional angles

value.description: the alpha beta CV

ALPHABETA.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the atoms involved for each of the torsions you wish to 
                          calculate. Keywords like ATOMS1, ATOMS2, ATOMS3,... should be listed 
                          and one torsion will be calculated for each ATOM keyword you 
                          specify. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. ATOMS1, 
                          ATOMS2, ATOMS3... 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
              REFERENCE - the reference values for each of the torsional angles. If 
                          you use a single REFERENCE value the same reference value is 
                          used for all torsions. You can use multiple instances of this 
                          keyword i.e. REFERENCE1, REFERENCE2, REFERENCE3... 
            COEFFICIENT - the coefficient for each of the torsional angles. If you 
                          use a single COEFFICIENT value the same reference value is used 
                          for all torsional angles. You can use multiple instances of 
                          this keyword i.e. COEFFICIENT1, COEFFICIENT2, COEFFICIENT3...

ALPHARMSD.description: Probe the alpha helical content of a protein structure.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions

MASK.description: a vector which is used to determine which elements of the secondary structure variable should be computed

RESIDUES.description: this command is used to specify the set of residues that could conceivably form part of the secondary structure

TYPE.description: the manner in which RMSD alignment is performed

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of a residue segments that are within a certain target distance of this secondary structure type

R_0.description: The r_0 parameter of the switching function

D_0.description: The d_0 parameter of the switching function

NN.description: The n parameter of the switching function

MM.description: The m parameter of the switching function

ALIGN_STRANDS.description: ensure that the two halves of a beta sheet are not broken by the periodic boundaries before doing alignment

struct.description: the vectors containing the rmsd distances between the residues and each of the reference structures

lessthan.description: the number blocks of residues that have an RMSD from the secondary structure that is less than the threshold

value.description: if LESS_THAN is present the RMSD distance between each residue and the ideal alpha helix

ALPHARMSD.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

               RESIDUES - this command is used to specify the set of residues that 
                          could conceivably form part of the secondary structure. It is 
                          possible to use residues numbers as the various chains and residues 
                          should have been identified else using an instance of the ef 
                          MOLINFO action. If you wish to use all the residues from all the 
                          chains in your system you can do so by specifying all. 
                          Alternatively, if you wish to use a subset of the residues you can specify 
                          the particular residues you are interested in as a list of 
                          numbers. Please be aware that to form secondary structure elements 
                          your chain must contain at least N residues, where N is 
                          dependent on the particular secondary structure you are interested 
                          in. As such if you define portions of the chain with fewer than 
                          N residues the code will crash. 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                   TYPE - ( default=DRMSD ) the manner in which RMSD alignment is 
                          performed. Should be OPTIMAL, SIMPLE or DRMSD. For more details on the 
                          OPTIMAL and SIMPLE methods see ef RMSD. For more details on the 
                          DRMSD method see ef DRMSD. 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                     NN - ( default=8 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=12 ) The m parameter of the switching function 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                VERBOSE - ( default=off ) write a more detailed output 
          ALIGN_STRANDS - ( default=off ) ensure that the two halves of a beta sheet 
                          are not broken by the periodic boundaries before doing 
                          alignment 
                   MASK - a vector which is used to determine which elements of the 
                          secondary structure variable should be computed 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of a residue segments that are within 
                          a certain target distance of this secondary structure type. 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

ATOMS.description: the list of atoms involved in this collective variable (either 3 or 4 atoms)

value.description: the ANGLE involving these atoms

ANGLE.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the list of atoms involved in this collective variable 
                          (either 3 or 4 atoms). For more information on how to specify lists 
                          of atoms see ef Group 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances

ANGLES.description: Calculate functions of the distribution of angles.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

GROUP.description: Calculate angles for each distinct set of three atoms in the group

GROUPA.description: A group of central atoms about which angles should be calculated

GROUPB.description: When used in conjunction with GROUPA this keyword instructs plumed to calculate all distinct angles involving one atom from GROUPA and two atoms from GROUPB

GROUPC.description: This must be used in conjunction with GROUPA and GROUPB

SWITCH.description: the switching function specifies that only those bonds that have a length that is less than a certain threshold are considered

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HIGHEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the highest of these variables

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

value.description: the ANGLE for each set of three atoms that were specified

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

ANGLES.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  GROUP - Calculate angles for each distinct set of three atoms in 
                          the group 
                 GROUPA - A group of central atoms about which angles should be 
                          calculated 
                 GROUPB - When used in conjunction with GROUPA this keyword instructs 
                          plumed to calculate all distinct angles involving one atom from 
                          GROUPA and two atoms from GROUPB. The atom from GROUPA is the 
                          central atom. 
                 GROUPC - This must be used in conjunction with GROUPA and GROUPB. 
                          All angles involving one atom from GROUPA, one atom from GROUPB 
                          and one atom from GROUPC are calculated. The GROUPA atoms are 
                          assumed to be the central atoms 

The following options are available

                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
                 SWITCH - the switching function specifies that only those bonds that 
                          have a length that is less than a certain threshold are 
                          considered 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

ATOMS.description: the list of atoms involved in this collective variable (either 3 or 4 atoms)

NO_ACTION_LOG.description: suppresses printing from action on the log

value.description: the ANGLE involving these atoms

ANGLE_SCALAR.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the list of atoms involved in this collective variable 
                          (either 3 or 4 atoms). For more information on how to specify lists 
                          of atoms see ef Group 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

ATOMS.description: the list of atoms involved in this collective variable (either 3 or 4 atoms)

NO_ACTION_LOG.description: suppresses printing from action on the log

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

MASK.description: the label for a sparse vector that should be used to determine which elements of the vector should be computed

value.description: the ANGLE for each set of specified atoms

ANGLE_VECTOR.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the list of atoms involved in this collective variable 
                          (either 3 or 4 atoms). For more information on how to specify lists 
                          of atoms see ef Group 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                   MASK - the label for a sparse vector that should be used to 
                          determine which elements of the vector should be computed

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the values from which the function is calculated

PERIODIC.description: if the output of your function is periodic then you should specify the periodicity of the function

NUM_LAYERS.description: number of layers of the neural network

NUM_NODES.description: numbers of nodes in each layer of the neural network

ACTIVATIONS.description: activation functions for the neural network

WEIGHTS.description: flattened weight arrays connecting adjacent layers, WEIGHTS0 represents flattened weight array connecting layer 0 and layer 1, WEIGHTS1 represents flattened weight array connecting layer 1 and layer 2,

BIASES.description: bias array for each layer of the neural network, BIASES0 represents bias array for layer 1, BIASES1 represents bias array for layer 2,

ANN.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the values from which the function is 
                          calculated 
               PERIODIC - if the output of your function is periodic then you should 
                          specify the periodicity of the function. If the output is not 
                          periodic you must state this using PERIODIC=NO 
             NUM_LAYERS - number of layers of the neural network 
              NUM_NODES - numbers of nodes in each layer of the neural network 
            ACTIVATIONS - activation functions for the neural network 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                WEIGHTS - flattened weight arrays connecting adjacent layers, 
                          WEIGHTS0 represents flattened weight array connecting layer 0 and 
                          layer 1, WEIGHTS1 represents flattened weight array connecting 
                          layer 1 and layer 2, .... You can use multiple instances of this 
                          keyword i.e. WEIGHTS1, WEIGHTS2, WEIGHTS3... 
                 BIASES - bias array for each layer of the neural network, BIASES0 
                          represents bias array for layer 1, BIASES1 represents bias array for 
                          layer 2, .... You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. 
                          BIASES1, BIASES2, BIASES3...

ANTIBETARMSD.description: Probe the antiparallel beta sheet content of your protein structure.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions

MASK.description: a vector which is used to determine which elements of the secondary structure variable should be computed

RESIDUES.description: this command is used to specify the set of residues that could conceivably form part of the secondary structure

ATOMS.description: this is the full list of atoms that we are investigating

TYPE.description: the manner in which RMSD alignment is performed

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of a residue segments that are within a certain target distance of this secondary structure type

R_0.description: The r_0 parameter of the switching function

D_0.description: The d_0 parameter of the switching function

NN.description: The n parameter of the switching function

MM.description: The m parameter of the switching function

ALIGN_STRANDS.description: ensure that the two halves of a beta sheet are not broken by the periodic boundaries before doing alignment

STYLE.description: Antiparallel beta sheets can either form in a single chain or from a pair of chains

STRANDS_CUTOFF.description: If in a segment of protein the two strands are further apart then the calculation of the actual RMSD is skipped as the structure is very far from being beta-sheet like

struct.description: the vectors containing the rmsd distances between the residues and each of the reference structures

lessthan.description: the number blocks of residues that have an RMSD from the secondary structure that is less than the threshold

value.description: if LESS_THAN is present the RMSD distance between each residue and the ideal antiparallel beta sheet

ANTIBETARMSD.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

               RESIDUES - this command is used to specify the set of residues that 
                          could conceivably form part of the secondary structure. It is 
                          possible to use residues numbers as the various chains and residues 
                          should have been identified else using an instance of the ef 
                          MOLINFO action. If you wish to use all the residues from all the 
                          chains in your system you can do so by specifying all. 
                          Alternatively, if you wish to use a subset of the residues you can specify 
                          the particular residues you are interested in as a list of 
                          numbers. Please be aware that to form secondary structure elements 
                          your chain must contain at least N residues, where N is 
                          dependent on the particular secondary structure you are interested 
                          in. As such if you define portions of the chain with fewer than 
                          N residues the code will crash. 
                  ATOMS - this is the full list of atoms that we are investigating. 
                          For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef 
                          Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                   TYPE - ( default=DRMSD ) the manner in which RMSD alignment is 
                          performed. Should be OPTIMAL, SIMPLE or DRMSD. For more details on the 
                          OPTIMAL and SIMPLE methods see ef RMSD. For more details on the 
                          DRMSD method see ef DRMSD. 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                     NN - ( default=8 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=12 ) The m parameter of the switching function 
                  STYLE - ( default=all ) Antiparallel beta sheets can either form in 
                          a single chain or from a pair of chains. If STYLE=all all 
                          chain configuration with the appropriate geometry are counted. If 
                          STYLE=inter only sheet-like configurations involving two chains are 
                          counted, while if STYLE=intra only sheet-like configurations 
                          involving a single chain are counted 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                VERBOSE - ( default=off ) write a more detailed output 
          ALIGN_STRANDS - ( default=off ) ensure that the two halves of a beta sheet 
                          are not broken by the periodic boundaries before doing 
                          alignment 
                   MASK - a vector which is used to determine which elements of the 
                          secondary structure variable should be computed 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of a residue segments that are within 
                          a certain target distance of this secondary structure type. 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function. 
         STRANDS_CUTOFF - If in a segment of protein the two strands are further 
                          apart then the calculation of the actual RMSD is skipped as the 
                          structure is very far from being beta-sheet like. This keyword speeds 
                          up the calculation enormously when you are using the LESS_THAN 
                          option. However, if you are using some other option, then this 
                          cannot be used

ARGS2VATOM.description: Create a virtual atom from the input scalars

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

XPOS.description: the value to use for the x position of the atom

YPOS.description: the value to use for the y position of the atom

ZPOS.description: the value to use for the z position of the atom

MASS.description: the value to use for the mass of the atom

CHARGE.description: the value to use for the charge of the atom

XBKP.description: x position to use in case PBC not set when using PHASES

YBKP.description: y position to use in case PBC not set when using PHASES

ZBKP.description: z position to use in case PBC not set when using PHASES

FRACTIONAL.description: the input arguments are calculated in fractional coordinates so you need to multiply by the cell

x.description: the x coordinate of the virtual atom

y.description: the y coordinate of the virtual atom

z.description: the z coordinate of the virtual atom

mass.description: the mass of the virtual atom

charge.description: the charge of the virtual atom

ARGS2VATOM.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                   XPOS - the value to use for the x position of the atom 
                   YPOS - the value to use for the y position of the atom 
                   ZPOS - the value to use for the z position of the atom 
                   MASS - the value to use for the mass of the atom 
                 CHARGE - the value to use for the charge of the atom 

In addition you may use the following options: 

             FRACTIONAL - ( default=off ) the input arguments are calculated in 
                          fractional coordinates so you need to multiply by the cell

AROUND.description: This quantity can be used to calculate functions of the distribution of collective variables for the atoms that lie in a particular, user-specified part of of the cell.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

ATOMS.description: the group of atoms that you would like to investigate

OUTSIDE.description: calculate quantities for colvars that are on atoms outside the region of interest

ORIGIN.description: the atom whose vicinity we are interested in examining

ATOM.description: You should use ORIGIN instead of this keyword which was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided for back compatibility only

SIGMA.description: the width of the function to be used for kernel density estimation

KERNEL.description: the type of kernel function to be used

XLOWER.description: the lower boundary in x relative to the x coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

XUPPER.description: the upper boundary in x relative to the x coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

YLOWER.description: the lower boundary in y relative to the y coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

YUPPER.description: the upper boundary in y relative to the y coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

ZLOWER.description: the lower boundary in z relative to the z coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

ZUPPER.description: the upper boundary in z relative to the z coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

DATA.description: the label of an action that calculates multicolvars

LESS_THAN.description: calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region of interest and that are less than a certain threshold

MORE_THAN.description: calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region of interest and that are greater that a certain threshold

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of colvars that are inside the region of interest and that have a CV value that is between a particular set of bounds

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the average value of the colvar inside the region of interest

value.description: sum of values of input CVs in regin of interest

lessthan.description: the number of cvs in the region of interest that are less than a certain threshold

morethan.description: the number of cvs in the region of interest that are more than a certain threshold

between.description: the number of cvs in the region of interest that are within a certain range

sum.description: the sum of all the colvars weighted by the function that determines if we are in the region

mean.description: the average values of the colvar in the region of interest

AROUND.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the group of atoms that you would like to investigate. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 ORIGIN - the atom whose vicinity we are interested in examining. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  SIGMA - the width of the function to be used for kernel density 
                          estimation 
                 KERNEL - ( default=gaussian ) the type of kernel function to be used 
                 XLOWER - ( default=0.0 ) the lower boundary in x relative to the x 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 XUPPER - ( default=0.0 ) the upper boundary in x relative to the x 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 YLOWER - ( default=0.0 ) the lower boundary in y relative to the y 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 YUPPER - ( default=0.0 ) the upper boundary in y relative to the y 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 ZLOWER - ( default=0.0 ) the lower boundary in z relative to the z 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 ZUPPER - ( default=0.0 ) the upper boundary in z relative to the z 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                OUTSIDE - ( default=off ) calculate quantities for colvars that are 
                          on atoms outside the region of interest 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the average value of the colvar 
                          inside the region of interest 
                   DATA - the label of an action that calculates multicolvars. 
                          Weighted sums based on the location of the colvars calculated by 
                          this action will be calcualted 
              LESS_THAN - calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region 
                          of interest and that are less than a certain threshold 
              MORE_THAN - calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region 
                          of interest and that are greater that a certain threshold 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of colvars that are inside the region 
                          of interest and that have a CV value that is between a 
                          particular set of bounds

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

ATOMS.description: the group of atoms that you would like to investigate

OUTSIDE.description: calculate quantities for colvars that are on atoms outside the region of interest

ORIGIN.description: the atom whose vicinity we are interested in examining

ATOM.description: You should use ORIGIN instead of this keyword which was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided for back compatibility only

SIGMA.description: the width of the function to be used for kernel density estimation

KERNEL.description: the type of kernel function to be used

XLOWER.description: the lower boundary in x relative to the x coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

XUPPER.description: the upper boundary in x relative to the x coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

YLOWER.description: the lower boundary in y relative to the y coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

YUPPER.description: the upper boundary in y relative to the y coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

ZLOWER.description: the lower boundary in z relative to the z coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

ZUPPER.description: the upper boundary in z relative to the z coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box)

value.description: vector of numbers between 0 and 1 that measure the degree to which each atom is within the volume of interest

AROUND_CALC.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the group of atoms that you would like to investigate. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 ORIGIN - the atom whose vicinity we are interested in examining. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  SIGMA - the width of the function to be used for kernel density 
                          estimation 
                 KERNEL - ( default=gaussian ) the type of kernel function to be used 
                 XLOWER - ( default=0.0 ) the lower boundary in x relative to the x 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 XUPPER - ( default=0.0 ) the upper boundary in x relative to the x 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 YLOWER - ( default=0.0 ) the lower boundary in y relative to the y 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 YUPPER - ( default=0.0 ) the upper boundary in y relative to the y 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 ZLOWER - ( default=0.0 ) the lower boundary in z relative to the z 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 
                 ZUPPER - ( default=0.0 ) the upper boundary in z relative to the z 
                          coordinate of the atom (0 indicates use full extent of box). 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                OUTSIDE - ( default=off ) calculate quantities for colvars that are 
                          on atoms outside the region of interest

ARRANGE_POINTS.description: Arrange points in a low dimensional space so that the (transformed) distances between points in the low dimensional space match the dissimilarities provided in an input matrix.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the initial positions for the projections

TARGET.description: the matrix of target quantities that you would like to match

FUNC.description: a function that is applied on the distances between the points in the low dimensional space

WEIGHTS.description: the matrix with the weights of the target quantities

MINTYPE.description: the method to use for the minimisation

MAXITER.description: maximum number of optimization cycles for optimisation algorithms

CGTOL.description: the tolerance for the conjugate gradient minimization

NCYCLES.description: the number of cycles of global optimization to attempt

BUFFER.description: grid extent for search is (max projection - minimum projection) multiplied by this value

CGRID_SIZE.description: number of points to use in each grid direction

FGRID_SIZE.description: interpolate the grid onto this number of points -- only works in 2D

SMACTOL.description: the tolerance for the smacof algorithm

SMACREG.description: this is used to ensure that we don't divide by zero when updating weights for SMACOF algorithm

coord.description: the coordinates of the points in the low dimensional space

ARRANGE_POINTS.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the initial positions for the projections 
                MINTYPE - ( default=conjgrad ) the method to use for the minimisation 
                MAXITER - ( default=1000 ) maximum number of optimization cycles for 
                          optimisation algorithms 
                  CGTOL - ( default=1E-6 ) the tolerance for the conjugate gradient 
                          minimization 
                NCYCLES - ( default=5 ) the number of cycles of global optimization 
                          to attempt 
                 BUFFER - ( default=1.1 ) grid extent for search is (max projection - 
                          minimum projection) multiplied by this value 
             CGRID_SIZE - ( default=10 ) number of points to use in each grid 
                          direction 
             FGRID_SIZE - ( default=0 ) interpolate the grid onto this number of 
                          points -- only works in 2D 
                SMACTOL - ( default=1E-4 ) the tolerance for the smacof algorithm 
                SMACREG - ( default=0.001 ) this is used to ensure that we don't 
                          divide by zero when updating weights for SMACOF algorithm 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                 TARGET - the matrix of target quantities that you would like to 
                          match. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. 
                          TARGET1, TARGET2, TARGET3... 
                   FUNC - a function that is applied on the distances between the 
                          points in the low dimensional space. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. FUNC1, FUNC2, FUNC3... 
                WEIGHTS - the matrix with the weights of the target quantities. You 
                          can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. WEIGHTS1, 
                          WEIGHTS2, WEIGHTS3...

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

SPECIES.description: the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments

SPECIESA.description: the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

SPECIESB.description: the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

SWITCH.description: the switching function that it used in the construction of the contact matrix

KERNEL.description: The kernels used in the function of the angle

SWITCH_COORD.description: This keyword is used to define the coordination switching function

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HIGHEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the highest of these variables

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

ATOMIC_SMAC.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                SPECIES - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments 
               SPECIESA - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESB, 
                          which specifies the atoms that are in the environment. 
               SPECIESB - the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each 
                          of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESA, 
                          which specifies the atoms for which the symmetry function is 
                          being calculated. 

The following options are available

                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
                 SWITCH - the switching function that it used in the construction of 
                          the contact matrix 
                 KERNEL - The kernels used in the function of the angle. You can use 
                          multiple instances of this keyword i.e. KERNEL1, KERNEL2, KERNEL3... 
           SWITCH_COORD - This keyword is used to define the coordination switching 
                          function. 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

AVERAGE.description: Calculate the ensemble average of a collective variable

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the quantity that is being averaged

LOGWEIGHTS.description: the logarithm of the quantity to use as the weights when calculating averages

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which to store data for averaging

CLEAR.description: the frequency with whihc to clear the data that is being averaged

NORMALIZATION.description: Including this keyword in the input to this action makes no difference to the calculation performed it was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided here for back compatibility only

value.description: the value of the average

AVERAGE.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the quantity that is being averaged 
                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which to store data for 
                          averaging 
                  CLEAR - ( default=0 ) the frequency with whihc to clear the data 
                          that is being averaged 
             LOGWEIGHTS - the logarithm of the quantity to use as the weights when 
                          calculating averages

AVERAGE_PATH_DISPLACEMENT.description: Accumulate the distances between the reference frames in the paths and the configurations visited

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the matrix that contains the vectors of displacements from each frame in the path

METRIC.description: the method to use for computing the displacement vectors between the reference frames

METRIC_COMPONENT.description: if the final action in your metric contains multiple components this keyword is used to specify the component that should be used

REFERENCE.description: labels for actions that contain reference coordinates for each point on the path

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the average displacements should be collected and added to the average displacements

HALFLIFE.description: the number of MD steps after which a previously measured path distance weighs only 50 percent in the average

CLEAR.description: the frequency with which to clear all the accumulated data

value.description: matrix containing the average displacement between the trajectory and each of the landmarks that makes up the path

AVERAGE_PATH_DISPLACEMENT.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the matrix that contains the vectors of 
                          displacements from each frame in the path 
                 METRIC - the method to use for computing the displacement vectors 
                          between the reference frames 
       METRIC_COMPONENT - if the final action in your metric contains multiple 
                          components this keyword is used to specify the component that should 
                          be used 
              REFERENCE - labels for actions that contain reference coordinates for 
                          each point on the path 
                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which the average 
                          displacements should be collected and added to the average displacements 
               HALFLIFE - ( default=-1 ) the number of MD steps after which a 
                          previously measured path distance weighs only 50 percent in the 
                          average. This option may increase convergence by allowing to forget 
                          the memory of a bad initial guess path. The default is to set 
                          this to infinity 
                  CLEAR - ( default=0 ) the frequency with which to clear all the 
                          accumulated data. The default value of 0 implies that all the data will 
                          be used and that the grid will never be cleared

                MAXIMUM - The maximum of the interval on which the basis functions 
                          are defined. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

             DEBUG_INFO - ( default=off ) Print out more detailed information about 
                          the basis set. Useful for debugging. 
               PERIODIC - ( default=off ) Use periodic version of basis set. 
          NORMALIZATION - the normalization factor that is used to normalize the 
                          basis functions by dividing the values. By default it is 2.

In addition you may use the following options:

                          expressions using _x_ as a variable.. You can use multiple instances of 
                          this keyword i.e. FUNC1, FUNC2, FUNC3...

                          argument before calculating the basis function values. You should 
                          use _t_ as a variable. You can use the variables _min_ and 
                          _max_ to give the minimum and the maximum of the interval.

TYPE.description: Specify the wavelet type

FUNCTION_LENGTH.description: The domain size of the individual basis functions

NUM_BF.description: The number of basis functions that should be used

TAILS_THRESHOLD.description: The threshold for cutting off tail wavelets as a fraction of the maximum value

MOTHER_WAVELET.description: If this flag is set mother wavelets will be used instead of the scaling function (father wavelet)

MIN_GRID_SIZE.description: The minimal number of grid bins of the Wavelet function

DUMP_WAVELET_GRID.description: If this flag is set the grid with the wavelet values will be written to a file

WAVELET_FILE_FMT.description: The number format of the wavelet grid values and derivatives written to file

PERIODIC.description: Use periodic version of basis set

BF_WAVELETS.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  ORDER - The order of the basis function expansion. 
                MINIMUM - The minimum of the interval on which the basis functions 
                          are defined. 
                MAXIMUM - The maximum of the interval on which the basis functions 
                          are defined. 
                   TYPE - Specify the wavelet type. Currently available are 
                          DAUBECHIES Wavelets with minimum phase and the more symmetric SYMLETS 

In addition you may use the following options: 

             DEBUG_INFO - ( default=off ) Print out more detailed information about 
                          the basis set. Useful for debugging. 
         MOTHER_WAVELET - ( default=off ) If this flag is set mother wavelets will be 
                          used instead of the scaling function (father wavelet). Makes 
                          only sense for multiresolution, which is at the moment not 
                          usable. 
      DUMP_WAVELET_GRID - ( default=off ) If this flag is set the grid with the 
                          wavelet values will be written to a file. This file is called 
                          wavelet_grid.data. 
               PERIODIC - ( default=off ) Use periodic version of basis set. 
        FUNCTION_LENGTH - The domain size of the individual basis functions. (length) 
                          This is used to alter the scaling of the basis functions. By 
                          default it is set to the total size of the interval. This also 
                          influences the number of actually used basis functions, as all shifted 
                          functions that are partially supported in the CV space are used. 
                 NUM_BF - The number of basis functions that should be used. Includes 
                          the constant one and N-1 shifted wavelets within the specified 
                          range. Cannot be used together with FUNCTION_LENGTH. 
        TAILS_THRESHOLD - The threshold for cutting off tail wavelets as a fraction 
                          of the maximum value. All shifted wavelet functions that only 
                          have values smaller than the threshold in the bias range will be 
                          excluded from the basis set. Defaults to 0 (include all). 
          MIN_GRID_SIZE - The minimal number of grid bins of the Wavelet function. 
                          The true number depends also on the used wavelet type and will 
                          probably be larger. Defaults to 1000. 
       WAVELET_FILE_FMT - The number format of the wavelet grid values and 
                          derivatives written to file. By default it is %15.8f.

BOPS.description: Calculate Bond orientational order parameters for molecules.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

SPECIES.description: this keyword is used for colvars such as coordination number

SPECIESA.description: this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination number

SPECIESB.description: this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination number

QUATERNIONS.description: the label of the action that computes the quaternions that should be used

KERNELFILE_DOPS.description: the file containing the list of kernel parameters

KERNELFILE_BOPS.description: the second file containing the list of kernel parameters

value.description: the values of the bops order parameters

BOPS.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                SPECIES - this keyword is used for colvars such as coordination 
                          number. In that context it specifies that plumed should calculate 
                          one coordination number for each of the atoms specified. Each 
                          of these coordination numbers specifies how many of the other 
                          specified atoms are within a certain cutoff of the central atom. You 
                          can specify the atoms here as another multicolvar action or 
                          using a MultiColvarFilter or ActionVolume action. When you do so 
                          the quantity is calculated for those atoms specified in the 
                          previous multicolvar. This is useful if you would like to calculate 
                          the Steinhardt parameter for those atoms that have a 
                          coordination number more than four for example. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
               SPECIESA - this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination 
                          number. In that context it species that plumed should calculate one 
                          coordination number for each of the atoms specified in SPECIESA. Each of 
                          these cooordination numbers specifies how many of the atoms 
                          specifies using SPECIESB is within the specified cutoff. As with the 
                          species keyword the input can also be specified using the label of 
                          another multicolvar 
               SPECIESB - this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination 
                          number. It must appear with SPECIESA. For a full explanation see 
                          the documentation for that keyword 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

            QUATERNIONS - the label of the action that computes the quaternions that 
                          should be used 
        KERNELFILE_DOPS - the file containing the list of kernel parameters. We 
                          expect h, mu and sigma parameters for a 1D Gaussian kernel of the 
                          form h*exp(-(x-mu)^2/2sigma^2) 
        KERNELFILE_BOPS - the second file containing the list of kernel parameters. 
                          Expecting a normalization factor (height), concentration parameter 
                          (kappa), and 3 norm vector pieces of the mean (mu_i, mu_j, mu_k )for 
                          a fisher distribution. of the form 
                          h*exp(kappa*dot(r_mean,r)), where dot is a standard dot product. 
                 CUTOFF - cutoff for the distance matrix

BRIDGE_MATRIX.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  GROUP - the atoms for which you would like to calculate the 
                          adjacency matrix. For more information on how to specify lists of 
                          atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPA - when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two 
                          sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along 
                          with the keyword GROUPB. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPB - when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two 
                          sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along 
                          with the keyword GROUPA. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                  ATOMS - the atoms for which you would like to calculate the 
                          adjacency matrix. This is a depracated syntax that is equivalent to 
                          GROUP. You are strongly recommened to use GROUP instead of ATOMS. 
         BRIDGING_ATOMS - The list of atoms that can form the bridge between the two 
                          interesting parts of the structure.. For more information on how to 
                          specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              NL_CUTOFF - ( default=0.0 ) The cutoff for the neighbor list. A value 
                          of 0 means we are not using a neighbor list 
              NL_STRIDE - ( default=1 ) The frequency with which we are updating the 
                          atoms in the neighbor list 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
             COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) also calculate the components of the vector 
                          connecting the atoms in the contact matrix 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) don't use pbc 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                   MASK - a vector that is used to used to determine which rows of 
                          the adjancency matrix to compute 
                 SWITCH - The parameters of the two switching functions in the above 
                          formula 
                SWITCHA - The switching function on the distance between bridging 
                          atoms and the atoms in group A 
                SWITCHB - The switching function on the distance between the bridging 
                          atoms and the atoms in group B

LESS_THAN.description: calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region of interest and that are less than a certain threshold

MORE_THAN.description: calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region of interest and that are greater that a certain threshold

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of colvars that are inside the region of interest and that have a CV value that is between a particular set of bounds

value.description: sum of values of input CVs in regin of interest

lessthan.description: the number of cvs in the region of interest that are less than a certain threshold

morethan.description: the number of cvs in the region of interest that are more than a certain threshold

between.description: the number of cvs in the region of interest that are within a certain range

CAVITY.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the group of atoms that you would like to investigate. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                    BOX - the positions of four atoms that define spatial extent of 
                          the cavity. For more information on how to specify lists of 
                          atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  SIGMA - the width of the function to be used for kernel density 
                          estimation 
                 KERNEL - ( default=gaussian ) the type of kernel function to be used 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                OUTSIDE - ( default=off ) calculate quantities for colvars that are 
                          on atoms outside the region of interest 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the average value of the colvar 
                          inside the region of interest 
                   DATA - the label of an action that calculates multicolvars. 
                          Weighted sums based on the location of the colvars calculated by 
                          this action will be calcualted 
              LESS_THAN - calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region 
                          of interest and that are less than a certain threshold 
              MORE_THAN - calcualte the number of colvars that are inside the region 
                          of interest and that are greater that a certain threshold 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of colvars that are inside the region 
                          of interest and that have a CV value that is between a 
                          particular set of bounds

                          center. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see 
                          ef Group 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 PHASES - ( default=off ) use trigonometric phases when computing 
                          position of center 
            SAFE_PHASES - ( default=off ) use trignomentric phases when computing 
                          position of center but also compute the center in ths usual way and 
                          use this when the pbc are not set. There are two reasons for 
                          using this option (1) you are doing something that you know is 
                          really weird or (2) you are an idiot 
                   MASS - ( default=off ) calculate the center of mass 
                WEIGHTS - what weights should be used when calculating the center. If 
                          this keyword is not present the geometric center is computed. If 
                          WEIGHTS=@Masses is used the center of mass is computed. If WEIGHTS=@charges 
                          the center of charge is computed. If the label of an action is 
                          provided PLUMED assumes that that action calculates a list of 
                          symmetry functions that can be used as weights. Lastly, an explicit 
                          list of numbers to use as weights can be provided

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

CLUSTER_DISTRIBUTION.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

               CLUSTERS - the label of the action that does the clustering 
                WEIGHTS - use the vector of values calculated by this action as 
                          weights rather than giving each atom a unit weight 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

In addition you may use the following options: 

                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of

COLLECT.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the label of the value whose time series is being stored 
                          for later analysis 
                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which the data should be 
                          collected and added to the quantity being averaged 
                  CLEAR - ( default=0 ) the frequency with which to clear all the 
                          accumulated data. The default value of 0 implies that all the data will 
                          be used and that the grid will never be cleared 
                   TYPE - ( default=auto ) required if you are collecting an object 
                          with rank>0. Should be vector/matrix and determines how data is 
                          stored. If rank==0 then data has to be stored as a vector 
            UPDATE_FROM - Only update this action from this time
