SWITCH.description: The switching functions to use for each of the contacts in your map

REFERENCE.description: A reference value for a given contact, by default is 0

WEIGHT.description: A weight value for a given contact, by default is 1

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the contacts in the input

CMDIST.description: calculate the distance with respect to the provided reference contact map

SERIAL.description: Perform the calculation in serial - for debug purpose

contact.description: By not using SUM or CMDIST each contact will be stored in a component

value.description: the sum of all the switching function on all the distances

CONTACTMAP.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the atoms involved in each of the contacts you wish to 
                          calculate. Keywords like ATOMS1, ATOMS2, ATOMS3,... should be listed 
                          and one contact will be calculated for each ATOM keyword you 
                          specify.. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. ATOMS1, 
                          ATOMS2, ATOMS3... 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 SWITCH - The switching functions to use for each of the contacts in 
                          your map. You can either specify a global switching function 
                          using SWITCH or one switching function for each contact. Details 
                          of the various switching functions you can use are provided on 
                          ef switchingfunction.. You can use multiple instances of this 
                          keyword i.e. SWITCH1, SWITCH2, SWITCH3... 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the contacts in 
                          the input 
                 CMDIST - ( default=off ) calculate the distance with respect to the 
                          provided reference contact map 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
              REFERENCE - A reference value for a given contact, by default is 0.0 
                          You can either specify a global reference value using REFERENCE 
                          or one reference value for each contact.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. REFERENCE1, REFERENCE2, REFERENCE3... 
                 WEIGHT - A weight value for a given contact, by default is 1.0 You 
                          can either specify a global weight value using WEIGHT or one 
                          weight value for each contact.. You can use multiple instances of 
                          this keyword i.e. WEIGHT1, WEIGHT2, WEIGHT3...

CONTACT_MATRIX.description: Adjacency matrix in which two atoms are adjacent if they are within a certain cutoff.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

MASK.description: a vector that is used to used to determine which rows of the adjancency matrix to compute

GROUPA.description: when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along with the keyword GROUPB

GROUPB.description: when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along with the keyword GROUPA

ATOMS.description: the atoms for which you would like to calculate the adjacency matrix

COMPONENTS.description: also calculate the components of the vector connecting the atoms in the contact matrix

NOPBC.description: don't use pbc

NL_CUTOFF.description: The cutoff for the neighbor list

NL_STRIDE.description: The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the neighbor list

NN.description: The n parameter of the switching function

MM.description: The m parameter of the switching function; 0 implies 2*NN

D_0.description: The d_0 parameter of the switching function

R_0.description: The r_0 parameter of the switching function

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

GROUP.description: specifies the list of atoms that should be assumed indistinguishable

SWITCH.description: the input for the switching function that acts upon the distance between each pair of atoms

w.description: a matrix containing the weights for the bonds between each pair of atoms

x.description: the projection of the bond on the x axis

y.description: the projection of the bond on the y axis

z.description: the projection of the bond on the z axis

value.description: a matrix containing the weights for the bonds between each pair of atoms

CONTACT_MATRIX.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                 GROUPA - when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two 
                          sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along 
                          with the keyword GROUPB. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPB - when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two 
                          sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along 
                          with the keyword GROUPA. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                  ATOMS - the atoms for which you would like to calculate the 
                          adjacency matrix. This is a depracated syntax that is equivalent to 
                          GROUP. You are strongly recommened to use GROUP instead of ATOMS. 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              NL_CUTOFF - ( default=0.0 ) The cutoff for the neighbor list. A value 
                          of 0 means we are not using a neighbor list 
              NL_STRIDE - ( default=1 ) The frequency with which we are updating the 
                          atoms in the neighbor list 
                     NN - ( default=6 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=0 ) The m parameter of the switching function; 0 
                          implies 2*NN 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
             COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) also calculate the components of the vector 
                          connecting the atoms in the contact matrix 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) don't use pbc 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                   MASK - a vector that is used to used to determine which rows of 
                          the adjancency matrix to compute 
                  GROUP - specifies the list of atoms that should be assumed 
                          indistinguishable. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. GROUP1, 
                          GROUP2, GROUP3... 
                 SWITCH - the input for the switching function that acts upon the 
                          distance between each pair of atoms. You can use multiple instances 
                          of this keyword i.e. SWITCH1, SWITCH2, SWITCH3...

COORDINATION.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                 GROUPA - First list of atoms. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPB - Second list of atoms (if empty, N*(N-1)/2 pairs in GROUPA 
                          are counted). For more information on how to specify lists of 
                          atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                     NN - ( default=6 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=0 ) The m parameter of the switching function; 0 
                          implies 2*NN 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
                   PAIR - ( default=off ) Pair only 1st element of the 1st group with 
                          1st element in the second, etc 
                  NLIST - ( default=off ) Use a neighbor list to speed up the 
                          calculation 
              NL_CUTOFF - The cutoff for the neighbor list 
              NL_STRIDE - The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the 
                          neighbor list 
                 SWITCH - This keyword is used if you want to employ an alternative 
                          to the continuous switching function defined above. The 
                          following provides information on the ef switchingfunction that are 
                          available. When this keyword is present you no longer need the NN, MM, 
                          D_0 and R_0 keywords.

COORDINATIONNUMBER.description: Calculate the coordination numbers of atoms so that you can then calculate functions of the distribution of

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

SPECIES.description: the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments

SPECIESA.description: the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

SPECIESB.description: the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

NN.description: The n parameter of the switching function

MM.description: The m parameter of the switching function; 0 implies 2*NN

D_0.description: The d_0 parameter of the switching function

R_0.description: The r_0 parameter of the switching function

SWITCH.description: the switching function that it used in the construction of the contact matrix

MASK.description: the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows of the matrix are computed

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HIGHEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the highest of these variables

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

R_POWER.description: the power to which you want to raise the distance

LOWMEM.description: Including this keyword in the input to this action makes no difference to the calculation performed it was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided here for back compatibility only

MOMENTS.description: the list of moments that you would like to calculate

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

value.description: the coordination numbers of the specified atoms

COORDINATIONNUMBER.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                SPECIES - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments 
               SPECIESA - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESB, 
                          which specifies the atoms that are in the environment. 
               SPECIESB - the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each 
                          of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESA, 
                          which specifies the atoms for which the symmetry function is 
                          being calculated. 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                     NN - ( default=6 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=0 ) The m parameter of the switching function; 0 
                          implies 2*NN 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function 
                R_POWER - the power to which you want to raise the distance 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
                 SWITCH - the switching function that it used in the construction of 
                          the contact matrix 
                   MASK - the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows 
                          of the matrix are computed 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN. 
                MOMENTS - the list of moments that you would like to calculate

MASK.description: the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows of the matrix are computed

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HIGHEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the highest of these variables

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

FUNCTION.description: the function of the bond vectors that you would like to evaluate

ALPHA.description: The alpha parameter of the angular function that is used for FCCUBIC

LOWMEM.description: Including this keyword in the input to this action makes no difference to the calculation performed it was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided here for back compatibility only

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

value.description: the symmetry function for each of the specified atoms

COORDINATION_SHELL_FUNCTION.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                SPECIES - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments 
               SPECIESA - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESB, 
                          which specifies the atoms that are in the environment. 
               SPECIESB - the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each 
                          of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESA, 
                          which specifies the atoms for which the symmetry function is 
                          being calculated. 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                     NN - ( default=6 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=0 ) The m parameter of the switching function; 0 
                          implies 2*NN 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function 
               FUNCTION - the function of the bond vectors that you would like to 
                          evaluate 
                    PHI - ( default=0.0 ) The Euler rotational angle phi 
                  THETA - ( default=0.0 ) The Euler rotational angle theta 
                    PSI - ( default=0.0 ) The Euler rotational angle psi 
                  ALPHA - ( default=3.0 ) The alpha parameter of the angular function 
                          that is used for FCCUBIC 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
                 SWITCH - the switching function that it used in the construction of 
                          the contact matrix 
                   MASK - the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows 
                          of the matrix are computed 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

COORD_ANGLES.description: Calculate functions of the distribution of angles between bonds in the first coordination spheres of a set of atoms

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

CATOMS.description: all the angles between the bonds that radiate out from these central atom are computed

GROUP.description: a list of angls between pairs of bonds connecting one of the atoms specified using the CATOM command and two of the atoms specified here are computed

SWITCH.description: the switching function specifies that only those bonds that have a length that is less than a certain threshold are considered

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

COORD_ANGLES.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                 CATOMS - all the angles between the bonds that radiate out from 
                          these central atom are computed. For more information on how to 
                          specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                  GROUP - a list of angls between pairs of bonds connecting one of 
                          the atoms specified using the CATOM command and two of the 
                          atoms specified here are computed. For more information on how to 
                          specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 SWITCH - the switching function specifies that only those bonds that 
                          have a length that is less than a certain threshold are 
                          considered 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

COVARIANCE_MATRIX.help:

                          vector of values. The elements of this vector are used as weights 
                          for the input data points. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

            UNORMALIZED - ( default=off ) do not divide by the sum of the weights 
                    ARG - the vectors of data from which we are calculating the 
                          covariance. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. ARG1, 
                          ARG2, ARG3...

CS2BACKBONE.description: Calculates the backbone chemical shifts for a protein.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the values from which the function is calculated

REWEIGHT.description: simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy

AVERAGING.description: Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean

LIKELIHOOD.description: the likelihood for the GENERIC metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN

DFTILDE.description: fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve ftilde

SCALEDATA.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling factor common to all values and replicas

SCALE0.description: initial value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MIN.description: minimum value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MAX.description: maximum value of the scaling factor

DSCALE.description: maximum MC move of the scaling factor

ADDOFFSET.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset common to all values and replicas

DOFFSET.description: maximum MC move of the offset

REGRES_ZERO.description: stride for regression with zero offset

SIGMA0.description: initial value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MIN.description: minimum value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MAX.description: maximum value of the uncertainty parameter

DSIGMA.description: maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter

OPTSIGMAMEAN.description: Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma mean, or to estimate it on the fly

SIGMA_MEAN0.description: starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate

SIGMA_MAX_STEPS.description: Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the SIGMA_MAX value is used

TEMP.description: the system temperature - this is only needed if code doesn't pass the temperature to plumed

STATUS_FILE.description: write a file with all the data useful for restart/continuation of Metainference

FMT.description: specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the number of digits in regtests)

WRITE_STRIDE.description: write the status to a file every N steps, this can be used for restart/continuation

NSELECT.description: range of values for selector [0, N-1]

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

SERIAL.description: Perform the calculation in serial - for debug purpose

ATOMS.description: The atoms to be included in the calculation, e

DATADIR.description: The folder with the experimental chemical shifts

TEMPLATE.description: A PDB file of the protein system

NEIGH_FREQ.description: Period in step for neighbor list update

CAMSHIFT.description: Set to TRUE if you to calculate a single CamShift score

NOEXP.description: Set to TRUE if you don't want to have fixed components with the experimental values

acceptFT.description: MC acceptance for general metainference f tilde value

biasDer.description: derivatives with respect to the bias

ha.description: the calculated Ha hydrogen chemical shifts

hn.description: the calculated H hydrogen chemical shifts

nh.description: the calculated N nitrogen chemical shifts

ca.description: the calculated Ca carbon chemical shifts

cb.description: the calculated Cb carbon chemical shifts

co.description: the calculated C' carbon chemical shifts

expha.description: the experimental Ha hydrogen chemical shifts

exphn.description: the experimental H hydrogen chemical shifts

expnh.description: the experimental N nitrogen chemical shifts

expca.description: the experimental Ca carbon chemical shifts

expcb.description: the experimental Cb carbon chemical shifts

expco.description: the experimental C' carbon chemical shifts

value.description: the backbone chemical shifts

CS2BACKBONE.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - The atoms to be included in the calculation, e.g. the whole 
                          protein.. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see 
                          ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              NOISETYPE - ( default=MGAUSS ) functional form of the noise 
                          (GAUSS,MGAUSS,OUTLIERS,MOUTLIERS,GENERIC) 
             LIKELIHOOD - ( default=GAUSS ) the likelihood for the GENERIC 
                          metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN 
                DFTILDE - ( default=0.1 ) fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve 
                          ftilde 
                 SCALE0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the scaling factor 
            SCALE_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                OFFSET0 - ( default=0.0 ) initial value of the offset 
           OFFSET_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                 SIGMA0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MIN - ( default=0.0 ) minimum value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MAX - ( default=10. ) maximum value of the uncertainty parameter 
           OPTSIGMAMEAN - ( default=NONE ) Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma 
                          mean, or to estimate it on the fly 
           WRITE_STRIDE - ( default=10000 ) write the status to a file every N steps, 
                          this can be used for restart/continuation 
                DATADIR - ( default=data/ ) The folder with the experimental chemical 
                          shifts. 
               TEMPLATE - ( default=template.pdb ) A PDB file of the protein system. 
             NEIGH_FREQ - ( default=20 ) Period in step for neighbor list update. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                DOSCORE - ( default=off ) activate metainference 
             NOENSEMBLE - ( default=off ) don't perform any replica-averaging 
               REWEIGHT - ( default=off ) simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy 
              SCALEDATA - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling 
                          factor common to all values and replicas 
              ADDOFFSET - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset 
                          common to all values and replicas 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
               CAMSHIFT - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you to calculate a single 
                          CamShift score. 
                  NOEXP - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you don't want to have fixed 
                          components with the experimental values. 
                    ARG - the labels of the values from which the function is 
                          calculated 
              AVERAGING - Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean 
              SCALE_MIN - minimum value of the scaling factor 
              SCALE_MAX - maximum value of the scaling factor 
                 DSCALE - maximum MC move of the scaling factor 
             OFFSET_MIN - minimum value of the offset 
             OFFSET_MAX - maximum value of the offset 
                DOFFSET - maximum MC move of the offset 
            REGRES_ZERO - stride for regression with zero offset 
                 DSIGMA - maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter 
            SIGMA_MEAN0 - starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate 
        SIGMA_MAX_STEPS - Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the 
                          SIGMA_MAX value is used 
                   TEMP - the system temperature - this is only needed if code 
                          doesn't pass the temperature to plumed 
               MC_STEPS - number of MC steps 
           MC_CHUNKSIZE - MC chunksize 
            STATUS_FILE - write a file with all the data useful for 
                          restart/continuation of Metainference 
                    FMT - specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the 
                          number of digits in regtests) 
               SELECTOR - name of selector 
                NSELECT - range of values for selector [0, N-1] 
                RESTART - allows per-action setting of restart (YES/NO/AUTO)

CUSTOM.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

               PERIODIC - if the output of your function is periodic then you should 
                          specify the periodicity of the function. If the output is not 
                          periodic you must state this using PERIODIC=NO 
                   FUNC - the function you wish to evaluate 
                    ARG - the values input to this function 
                    VAR - the names to give each of the arguments in the function. If 
                          you have up to three arguments in your function you can use x, 
                          y and z to refer to them. Otherwise you must use this flag to 
                          give your variables names. 
                   MASK - the label for a sparse vector/matrix that should be used to 
                          determine which elements of the vector/matrix should be computed

NLIST.description: Use a neighbor list to speed up the calculation

NL_CUTOFF.description: The cutoff for the neighbor list

NL_STRIDE.description: The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the neighbor list

GROUPA.description: First list of atoms

GROUPB.description: Second list of atoms (if empty, N*(N-1)/2 pairs in GROUPA are counted)

TEMP.description: Simulation temperature (K)

value.description: the value of the DHENERGY

DHENERGY.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                 GROUPA - First list of atoms. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPB - Second list of atoms (if empty, N*(N-1)/2 pairs in GROUPA 
                          are counted). For more information on how to specify lists of 
                          atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                      I - ( default=1.0 ) Ionic strength (M) 
                   TEMP - ( default=300.0 ) Simulation temperature (K) 
                EPSILON - ( default=80.0 ) Dielectric constant of solvent 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
                   PAIR - ( default=off ) Pair only 1st element of the 1st group with 
                          1st element in the second, etc 
                  NLIST - ( default=off ) Use a neighbor list to speed up the 
                          calculation 
              NL_CUTOFF - The cutoff for the neighbor list 
              NL_STRIDE - The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the 
                          neighbor list

DIAGONALIZE.description: Calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a square matrix

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the input matrix

MATRIX.description: You should use ARG instead of this keyword which was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided for back compatibility only

VECTORS.description: the eigenvalues and vectors that you would like to calculate

vals.description: the eigevalues of the input matrix

vecs.description: the eigenvectors of the input matrix

DIAGONALIZE.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the input matrix 
                VECTORS - ( default=all ) the eigenvalues and vectors that you would 
                          like to calculate. 1=largest, 2=second largest and so on

DIMER.description: This CV computes the dimer interaction energy for a collection of dimers.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

DSIGMA.description: The interaction strength of the dimer bond

Q.description: The exponent of the dimer potential

TEMP.description: The temperature (in Kelvin) of the simulation

ATOMS1.description: The list of atoms representing the first bead of each Dimer being considered by this CV

ATOMS2.description: The list of atoms representing the second bead of each Dimer being considered by this CV

ALLATOMS.description: Use EVERY atom of the system

NOVSITES.description: If present the configuration is without virtual sites at the centroid positions

value.description: the dimer interaction energy

DIMER.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                 ATOMS1 - The list of atoms representing the first bead of each Dimer 
                          being considered by this CV. Used if ALLATOMS flag is missing. 
                          For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef 
                          Group 
                 ATOMS2 - The list of atoms representing the second bead of each 
                          Dimer being considered by this CV. Used if ALLATOMS flag is 
                          missing. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see 
                          ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 DSIGMA - The interaction strength of the dimer bond. 
                      Q - The exponent of the dimer potential. 
                   TEMP - The temperature (in Kelvin) of the simulation. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
               ALLATOMS - ( default=off ) Use EVERY atom of the system. Overrides 
                          ATOMS keyword. 
               NOVSITES - ( default=off ) If present the configuration is without 
                          virtual sites at the centroid positions.

                          dipole separately and store them as label.x, label.y and label.z

DISPLACEMENT.description: Calculate the displacement vector between the pair of input vectors

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

ARG2.description: The point that we are calculating the distance to

value.description: the differences between the input arguments

DISPLACEMENT.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                   ARG1 - The point that we are calculating the distance from 
                   ARG2 - The point that we are calculating the distance to

DISSIMILARITIES.description: Calculate the matrix of dissimilarities between a trajectory of atomic configurations.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

MASK.description: a matrix that is used to used to determine which elements of the output matrix to compute

ARG.description: the label of the two matrices from which the product is calculated

ELEMENTS_ON_DIAGONAL_ARE_ZERO.description: set all diagonal elements to zero

SQUARED.description: calculate the squares of the dissimilarities (this option cannot be used with MATRIX_PRODUCT)

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

value.description: the dissimilarity matrix

DISSIMILARITIES.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the label of the two matrices from which the product is 
                          calculated 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
ELEMENTS_ON_DIAGONAL_ARE_ZERO - ( default=off ) set all diagonal elements to zero 
                SQUARED - ( default=off ) calculate the squares of the 
                          dissimilarities (this option cannot be used with MATRIX_PRODUCT) 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                   MASK - a matrix that is used to used to determine which elements 
                          of the output matrix to compute

DISTANCE.description: Calculate the distance/s between pairs of atoms.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

ATOMS.description: the pair of atom that we are calculating the distance between

COMPONENTS.description: calculate the x, y and z components of the distance separately and store them as label

SCALED_COMPONENTS.description: calculate the a, b and c scaled components of the distance separately and store them as label

x.description: the x-component of the vector connecting the two atoms

y.description: the y-component of the vector connecting the two atoms

z.description: the z-component of the vector connecting the two atoms

a.description: the normalized projection on the first lattice vector of the vector connecting the two atoms

b.description: the normalized projection on the second lattice vector of the vector connecting the two atoms

c.description: the normalized projection on the third lattice vector of the vector connecting the two atoms

value.description: the DISTANCE between this pair of atoms

DISTANCE.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the pair of atom that we are calculating the distance 
                          between. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see 
                          ef Group 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
             COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) calculate the x, y and z components of the 
                          distance separately and store them as label.x, label.y and label.z 
      SCALED_COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) calculate the a, b and c scaled components 
                          of the distance separately and store them as label.a, label.b 
                          and label.c

DISTANCES.description: Calculate the distances between multiple piars of atoms

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

GROUP.description: Calculate the distance between each distinct pair of atoms in the group

GROUPA.description: Calculate the distances between all the atoms in GROUPA and all the atoms in GROUPB

GROUPB.description: Calculate the distances between all the atoms in GROUPA and all the atoms in GROUPB

ATOMS.description: the pairs of atoms that you would like to calculate the angles for

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

COMPONENTS.description: calculate the x, y and z components of the distance separately and store them as label

SCALED_COMPONENTS.description: calculate the a, b and c scaled components of the distance separately and store them as label

LOWMEM.description: Including this keyword in the input to this action makes no difference to the calculation performed it was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided here for back compatibility only

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HIGHEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the highest of these variables

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

ORIGIN.description: calculate the distance of all the atoms specified using the ATOMS keyword from this point

LOCATION.description: the location at which the CV is assumed to be in space

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

value.description: the DISTANCES between the each pair of atoms that were specified

x.description: the x-components of the distance vectors

y.description: the y-components of the distance vectors

z.description: the z-components of the distance vectors

DISTANCES.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  GROUP - Calculate the distance between each distinct pair of atoms 
                          in the group 
                 GROUPA - Calculate the distances between all the atoms in GROUPA and 
                          all the atoms in GROUPB. This must be used in conjunction with 
                          GROUPB. 
                 GROUPB - Calculate the distances between all the atoms in GROUPA and 
                          all the atoms in GROUPB. This must be used in conjunction with 
                          GROUPA. 
                  ATOMS - the pairs of atoms that you would like to calculate the 
                          angles for. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. 
                          ATOMS1, ATOMS2, ATOMS3... 
                 ORIGIN - calculate the distance of all the atoms specified using the 
                          ATOMS keyword from this point. For more information on how to 
                          specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
               LOCATION - the location at which the CV is assumed to be in space. You 
                          can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. LOCATION1, 
                          LOCATION2, LOCATION3... 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
             COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) calculate the x, y and z components of the 
                          distance separately and store them as label.x, label.y and label.z 
      SCALED_COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) calculate the a, b and c scaled components 
                          of the distance separately and store them as label.a, label.b 
                          and label.c 
                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

DISTANCE_FROM_CONTOUR.description: Calculate the perpendicular distance from a Willard-Chandler dividing surface.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the label of the weights to use when constructing the density

POSITIONS.description: the positions of the atoms that we are calculating the contour from

ATOM.description: The atom whose perpendicular distance we are calculating from the contour

BANDWIDTH.description: the bandwidths for kernel density esimtation

KERNEL.description: the kernel function you are using

CUTOFF.description: the cutoff at which to stop evaluating the kernel functions is set equal to sqrt(2*x)*bandwidth in each direction where x is this number

CONTOUR.description: the value we would like for the contour

DIR.description: the direction perpendicular to the contour that you are looking for

TOLERANCE.description: this parameter is used to manage periodic boundary conditions

dist1.description: the distance between the reference atom and the nearest contour

dist2.description: the distance between the reference atom and the other contour

qdist.description: the differentiable (squared) distance between the two contours (see above)

thickness.description: the distance between the two contours on the line from the reference atom

DISTANCE_FROM_CONTOUR.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

              POSITIONS - the positions of the atoms that we are calculating the 
                          contour from. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms 
                          see ef Group 
                   ATOM - The atom whose perpendicular distance we are calculating 
                          from the contour. For more information on how to specify lists 
                          of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              BANDWIDTH - the bandwidths for kernel density esimtation 
                 KERNEL - ( default=GAUSSIAN ) the kernel function you are using. 
                          More details on the kernels available in plumed plumed can be 
                          found in ef kernelfunctions. 
                 CUTOFF - ( default=6.25 ) the cutoff at which to stop evaluating the 
                          kernel functions is set equal to sqrt(2*x)*bandwidth in each 
                          direction where x is this number 
                CONTOUR - the value we would like for the contour 
                    DIR - the direction perpendicular to the contour that you are 
                          looking for 
              TOLERANCE - ( default=0.1 ) this parameter is used to manage periodic 
                          boundary conditions. The problem here is that we can be between 
                          contours even when we are not within the membrane because of 
                          periodic boundary conditions. When we are in the contour, however, 
                          we should have it so that the sums of the absolute values of 
                          the distances to the two contours is approximately the distance 
                          between the two contours. There can be numerical errors in these 
                          calculations, however, so we specify a small tolerance here 
                    ARG - the label of the weights to use when constructing the 
                          density. If this keyword is not here the weights are assumed to be 
                          one.

DISTANCE_FROM_SPHERICAL_CONTOUR.description: Calculate the perpendicular distance from a Willard-Chandler dividing surface.

The following arguments are compulsory:

                 KERNEL - ( default=GAUSSIAN ) the kernel function you are using. 
                          More details on the kernels available in plumed plumed can be

                 CUTOFF - ( default=6.25 ) the cutoff at which to stop evaluating the
