FAKE.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the fake atom index, a number is enough. For more 
                          information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

               PERIODIC - if the output of your function is periodic then you should 
                          specify the periodicity of the function. If the output is not 
                          periodic you must state this using PERIODIC=NO,NO (one for the lower 
                          and the other for the upper boundary). For multicomponents then 
                          it is PERIODIC=mincomp1,maxcomp1,mincomp2,maxcomp2 etc 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
             COMPONENTS - additional components that this variable is supposed to 
                          have. Periodicity is ruled by PERIODIC keyword

SPECIESA.description: the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

SPECIESB.description: the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

NN.description: The n parameter of the switching function

MM.description: The m parameter of the switching function; 0 implies 2*NN

D_0.description: The d_0 parameter of the switching function

R_0.description: The r_0 parameter of the switching function

SWITCH.description: the switching function that it used in the construction of the contact matrix

MASK.description: the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows of the matrix are computed

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HIGHEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the highest of these variables

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

FUNCTION.description: the function of the bond vectors that you would like to evaluate

ALPHA.description: The alpha parameter of the angular function that is used for FCCUBIC

LOWMEM.description: Including this keyword in the input to this action makes no difference to the calculation performed it was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided here for back compatibility only

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

value.description: the symmetry function for each of the specified atoms

FCCUBIC.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                SPECIES - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments 
               SPECIESA - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESB, 
                          which specifies the atoms that are in the environment. 
               SPECIESB - the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each 
                          of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESA, 
                          which specifies the atoms for which the symmetry function is 
                          being calculated. 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                     NN - ( default=6 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=0 ) The m parameter of the switching function; 0 
                          implies 2*NN 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function 
               FUNCTION - the function of the bond vectors that you would like to 
                          evaluate 
                    PHI - ( default=0.0 ) The Euler rotational angle phi 
                  THETA - ( default=0.0 ) The Euler rotational angle theta 
                    PSI - ( default=0.0 ) The Euler rotational angle psi 
                  ALPHA - ( default=3.0 ) The alpha parameter of the angular function 
                          that is used for FCCUBIC 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
                 SWITCH - the switching function that it used in the construction of 
                          the contact matrix 
                   MASK - the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows 
                          of the matrix are computed 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the grid in which the contour will be found

CONTOUR.description: the value we would like to draw the contour at in the space

INTERPOLATION_TYPE.description: the method to use for interpolation

ZERO_OUTSIDE_GRID_RANGE.description: if we are asked to evaluate the function for a number that is outside the range of the grid set it to zero

BUFFER.description: number of buffer grid points around location where grid was found on last step

value.description: interpolation of the input grid to get the value of the function at the input arguments

.#!custom.description: the names of the output components for this action depend on the actions input file see the example inputs below for details

FIND_CONTOUR.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the grid in which the contour will be found 
                CONTOUR - the value we would like to draw the contour at in the space 
     INTERPOLATION_TYPE - ( default=spline ) the method to use for interpolation. Can 
                          be spline, linear, ceiling or floor. 
                 BUFFER - ( default=0 ) number of buffer grid points around location 
                          where grid was found on last step. If this is zero the full grid 
                          is calculated on each step 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
ZERO_OUTSIDE_GRID_RANGE - ( default=off ) if we are asked to evaluate the function 
                          for a number that is outside the range of the grid set it to 
                          zero

FIND_CONTOUR_SURFACE.description: Find an isocontour by searching along either the x, y or z direction.

ARG.description: the labels of the grid in which the contour will be found

CONTOUR.description: the value we would like to draw the contour at in the space

INTERPOLATION_TYPE.description: the method to use for interpolation

ZERO_OUTSIDE_GRID_RANGE.description: if we are asked to evaluate the function for a number that is outside the range of the grid set it to zero

SEARCHDIR.description: In which directions do you wish to search for the contour

value.description: a grid containing the location of the points in the Willard-Chandler surface along the chosen direction

FIND_CONTOUR_SURFACE.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the grid in which the contour will be found 
                CONTOUR - the value we would like to draw the contour at in the space 
     INTERPOLATION_TYPE - ( default=spline ) the method to use for interpolation. Can 
                          be spline, linear, ceiling or floor. 
              SEARCHDIR - In which directions do you wish to search for the contour. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
ZERO_OUTSIDE_GRID_RANGE - ( default=off ) if we are asked to evaluate the function 
                          for a number that is outside the range of the grid set it to 
                          zero

FIND_GRID_MAXIMUM.description: Find the point with the highest value of the function on the grid

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the label for the function on the grid that you would like to find the optimum in

NOINTERPOL.description: do not interpolate the function when finding the optimum

CGTOL.description: the tolerance for the conjugate gradient optimization

optval.description: the value of the function at the optimum

_opt.description: the values of the arguments of the function at the optimum can be referenced elsewhere in the input file by using the names of the arguments followed by the string _opt

FIND_GRID_MAXIMUM.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the label for the function on the grid that you would like 
                          to find the optimum in 
                  CGTOL - ( default=1E-4 ) the tolerance for the conjugate gradient 
                          optimization 

In addition you may use the following options:

                          parallelize 
             NOINTERPOL - ( default=off ) do not interpolate the function when 
                          finding the optimum

optval.description: the value of the function at the optimum

_opt.description: the values of the arguments of the function at the optimum can be referenced elsewhere in the input file by using the names of the arguments followed by the string _opt

FIND_GRID_MINIMUM.help:

FIND_SPHERICAL_CONTOUR.description: Find an isocontour in a three dimensional grid by searching over a Fibonacci sphere.

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the grid in which the contour will be found

CONTOUR.description: the value we would like to draw the contour at in the space

INNER_RADIUS.description: the minimum radius on which to look for the contour

OUTER_RADIUS.description: the outer radius on which to look for the contour

In addition you may use the following options:

ZERO_OUTSIDE_GRID_RANGE - ( default=off ) if we are asked to evaluate the function

FISST.description: Compute and apply the optimal linear force on an observable to enhance sampling of conformational distributions over a range of applied forces.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the forces due to the bias should be calculated

PERIOD.description: Steps corresponding to the learning rate

RESET_PERIOD.description: Reset the learning statistics every time this number of steps comes around

NINTERPOLATE.description: Number of grid points on which to do interpolation

MIN_FORCE.description: Minimum force (per CV) to use for sampling

MAX_FORCE.description: Maximum force (per CV) to use for sampling

CENTER.description: The CV value at which the applied bias energy will be zero

KBT.description: The system temperature in units of KB*T

INITIAL_WEIGHT_DIST.description: Starting distribution for the force weights (options: UNIFORM, EXP, GAUSS)

INITIAL_WEIGHT_RATE.description: Rate of decay for exponential and gaussian distributions

RESTART_FMT.description: the format that should be used to output real numbers in FISST restarts

OUT_RESTART.description: Output file for all information needed to continue FISST simulation

IN_RESTART.description: Read this file to continue an FISST simulation

OUT_OBSERVABLE.description: Output file putting weights needed to compute observables at different force values

FREEZE.description: Fix bias weights at current level (only used for restarting)

bias.description: the instantaneous value of the bias potential

force2.description: squared value of force from the bias

_fbar.description: For each named CV biased, there will be a corresponding output CV_fbar storing the current linear bias prefactor

FISST.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act 
                 PERIOD - Steps corresponding to the learning rate 
           NINTERPOLATE - Number of grid points on which to do interpolation. 
              MIN_FORCE - Minimum force (per CV) to use for sampling. Units: 
                          [Energy]/[CV] (can be negative). 
              MAX_FORCE - Maximum force (per CV) to use for sampling. 
                 CENTER - ( default=0 ) The CV value at which the applied bias energy 
                          will be zero 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                 FREEZE - ( default=off ) Fix bias weights at current level (only 
                          used for restarting). 
           RESET_PERIOD - Reset the learning statistics every time this number of 
                          steps comes around. 
                    KBT - The system temperature in units of KB*T. If not provided 
                          will be taken from MD code (if available) 
    INITIAL_WEIGHT_DIST - Starting distribution for the force weights (options: 
                          UNIFORM, EXP, GAUSS). 
    INITIAL_WEIGHT_RATE - Rate of decay for exponential and gaussian distributions. 
                          W(F)~exp(-r |F|^d). 
            RESTART_FMT - the format that should be used to output real numbers in 
                          FISST restarts. 
            OUT_RESTART - Output file for all information needed to continue FISST 
                          simulation.If you have the RESTART directive set (global or for FISST), 
                          this file will be appended to.Note that the header will be 
                          printed again if appending. 
             IN_RESTART - Read this file to continue an FISST simulation. If same as 
                          OUT_RESTART and you have not set the RESTART directive, the file will 
                          be backed-up and overwritten with new output.If you do have 
                          the RESTART flag set and it is the same name as OUT_RESTART, 
                          this file will be appended. 
         OUT_OBSERVABLE - Output file putting weights needed to compute observables 
                          at different force values.If you have the RESTART directive 
                          set (global or for FISST), this file will be appended to. Note 
                          that the header will be printed again if appending. 
        OBSERVABLE_FREQ - How often to write out observable weights (default=period). 
                RESTART - allows per-action setting of restart (YES/NO/AUTO)

FIT_TO_TEMPLATE.description: This action is used to align a molecule to a template.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which molecules are reassembled

REFERENCE.description: a file in pdb format containing the reference structure and the atoms involved in the CV

TYPE.description: the manner in which RMSD alignment is performed

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

FIT_TO_TEMPLATE.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which molecules are 
                          reassembled. Unless you are completely certain about what you are doing 
                          leave this set equal to 1! 
              REFERENCE - a file in pdb format containing the reference structure and 
                          the atoms involved in the CV. 
                   TYPE - ( default=SIMPLE ) the manner in which RMSD alignment is 
                          performed. Should be OPTIMAL or SIMPLE. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances

FIXEDATOM.description: Add a virtual atom in a fixed position.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

ATOMS.description: the list of atoms which are involved the virtual atom's definition

FIXEDATOM.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                     AT - coordinates of the virtual atom 
               SET_MASS - ( default=1 ) mass of the virtual atom 
             SET_CHARGE - ( default=0 ) charge of the virtual atom 

In addition you may use the following options: 

      SCALED_COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) use scaled components

FLATTEN.description: Convert a matrix into a vector

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the label for the matrix that you would like to flatten to a vector

MASKED_INPUT_ALLOWED.description: turns on that you are allowed to use masked inputs

value.description: a vector containing all the elements of the input matrix

FLATTEN.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the label for the matrix that you would like to flatten to 
                          a vector

FLUSH.description: This command instructs plumed to flush all the open files with a user specified frequency.

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which all the open files should be flushed

FLUSH.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 STRIDE - the frequency with which all the open files should be 
                          flushed

FOURIER_TRANSFORM.description: Compute the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) by means of FFTW of data stored on a 2D grid.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the label of the grid that you want to fourer transform

FT_TYPE.description: choose what kind of data you want as output on the grid

FOURIER_PARAMETERS.description: what kind of normalization is applied to the output and if the Fourier transform in FORWARD or BACKWARD

real.description: the real part of the function

imag.description: the imaginary part of the function

value.description: the fourier transform of the input grid

FOURIER_TRANSFORM.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the label of the grid that you want to fourer transform 
     FOURIER_PARAMETERS - ( default=default ) what kind of normalization is applied 
                          to the output and if the Fourier transform in FORWARD or 
                          BACKWARD. This keyword takes the form FOURIER_PARAMETERS=A,B, where A 
                          and B can be 0, 1 or -1. The default values are A=1 (no 
                          normalization at all) and B=1 (forward FFT). Other possible choices for A 
                          are: A=-1: normalize by the number of data, A=0: normalize by 
                          the square root of the number of data (one forward and followed 
                          by backward FFT recover the original data). 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                FT_TYPE - choose what kind of data you want as output on the grid. 
                          Possible values are: ABS = compute the complex modulus of Fourier 
                          coefficients (DEFAULT); NORM = compute the norm (i.e. ABS^2) of Fourier 
                          coefficients; COMPLEX = store the FFTW complex output on the grid (as a 
                          vector).

                          between. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see

The following arguments are compulsory:

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances

NEIGH_STRIDE.description: How often the neighbor list needs to be calculated in time units

z.description: Distance from the path

                          CVs

                          units

FUNCSUMHILLS.description: This function is intended to be called by the command line tool sum_hills.  It is meant to integrate a HILLS file or an HILLS file interpreted as a histogram in a variety of ways. It is, therefore, not expected that you use this during your dynamics (it will crash!)

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the values from which the function is calculated

HILLSFILES.description: source file for hills creation(may be the same as HILLS)

HISTOFILES.description: source file for histogram creation(may be the same as HILLS)

HISTOSIGMA.description: sigmas for binning when the histogram correction is needed

PROJ.description: only with sumhills: the projection on the CVs

KT.description: only with sumhills: the kt factor when projection on CVs

GRID_MIN.description: the lower bounds for the grid

GRID_MAX.description: the upper bounds for the grid

GRID_BIN.description: the number of bins for the grid

GRID_SPACING.description: the approximate grid spacing (to be used as an alternative or together with GRID_BIN)

INITSTRIDE.description: stride if you want an initial dump

STRIDE.description: stride when you do it on the fly

ISCLTOOL.description: use via plumed command line: calculate at read phase and then go

NEGBIAS.description: dump  negative bias ( -bias )   instead of the free energy: needed in well tempered with flexible hills

NOHISTORY.description: to be used with INITSTRIDE:  it splits the bias/histogram in pieces without previous history

MINTOZERO.description: translate the resulting bias/histogram to have the minimum to zero

FMT.description: the format that should be used to output real numbers

value.description: a scalar

FUNCSUMHILLS.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the values from which the function is 
                          calculated 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
               ISCLTOOL - ( default=off ) use via plumed command line: calculate at 
                          read phase and then go 
           PARALLELREAD - ( default=off ) read parallel HILLS file 
                NEGBIAS - ( default=off ) dump negative bias ( -bias ) instead of the 
                          free energy: needed in well tempered with flexible hills 
              NOHISTORY - ( default=off ) to be used with INITSTRIDE: it splits the 
                          bias/histogram in pieces without previous history 
              MINTOZERO - ( default=off ) translate the resulting bias/histogram to 
                          have the minimum to zero 
             HILLSFILES - source file for hills creation(may be the same as HILLS) 
             HISTOFILES - source file for histogram creation(may be the same as 
                          HILLS) 
             HISTOSIGMA - sigmas for binning when the histogram correction is needed 
                   PROJ - only with sumhills: the projection on the CVs 
                     KT - only with sumhills: the kt factor when projection on CVs 
               GRID_MIN - the lower bounds for the grid 
               GRID_MAX - the upper bounds for the grid 
               GRID_BIN - the number of bins for the grid 
           GRID_SPACING - the approximate grid spacing (to be used as an alternative 
                          or together with GRID_BIN) 
               INTERVAL - set one dimensional INTERVAL 
               OUTHILLS - output file for hills 
               OUTHISTO - output file for histogram 
             INITSTRIDE - stride if you want an initial dump 
                 STRIDE - stride when you do it on the fly 
                    FMT - the format that should be used to output real numbers

FUNNEL.description: Calculate a funnel-shape restraint potential that is defined on a grid that is read during the setup.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the forces due to the bias should be calculated

NOSPLINE.description: specifies that no spline interpolation is to be used when calculating the energy and forces due to the external potential

SPARSE.description: specifies that the external potential uses a sparse grid

SPHERE.description: The Funnel potential including the binding site can be spherical instead of a cone

SCALE.description: a factor that multiplies the external potential, useful to invert free energies

KAPPA.description: constant to be used for the funnel-shape restraint potential

SAFETY.description: To be used in case the SPHERE flag is chosen, it regulates how much the potential extends (in nm)

SLOPE.description: Adjust the behavior of the potential outside the funnel, greater values than 1

ALPHA.description: angle to change the width of the cone section

ZCC.description: switching point between cylinder and cone

FILE.description: name of the Funnel potential file

WALKERS_MPI.description: To be used when gromacs + multiple walkers are used

bias.description: the instantaneous value of the bias potential

FUNNEL.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act 
                  SCALE - ( default=1.0 ) a factor that multiplies the external 
                          potential, useful to invert free energies 
                   MAXS - ( default=MAXS ) maximum value assumed by fps.lp 
                    ZCC - ( default=ZCC ) switching point between cylinder and cone 
                   FILE - name of the Funnel potential file 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
               NOSPLINE - ( default=off ) specifies that no spline interpolation is 
                          to be used when calculating the energy and forces due to the 
                          external potential 
                 SPARSE - ( default=off ) specifies that the external potential uses 
                          a sparse grid 
                 SPHERE - ( default=off ) The Funnel potential including the binding 
                          site can be spherical instead of a cone 
            WALKERS_MPI - ( default=off ) To be used when gromacs + multiple walkers 
                          are used 
                  NBINS - number of bins along fps.lp 
                  NBINZ - number of bins along fps.ld 
                   MINS - minimum value assumed by fps.lp, if the ligand is able to 
                          go beyond this value the simulation will crash 
                  KAPPA - constant to be used for the funnel-shape restraint 
                          potential 
                   RCYL - radius of the cylindrical section 
                 SAFETY - To be used in case the SPHERE flag is chosen, it regulates 
                          how much the potential extends (in nm) 
                  SLOPE - Adjust the behavior of the potential outside the funnel, 
                          greater values than 1.0 will tend to push the ligand more towards 
                          the cylinder and vice versa 
                  ALPHA - angle to change the width of the cone section

FUNNEL_PS.description: FUNNEL_PS implements the Funnel-Metadynamics (FM) technique in PLUMED 2.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

REFERENCE.description: a file in pdb format containing the structure you would like to align

LIGAND.description: This MUST be a single atom, normally the COM of the ligand

ANCHOR.description: Closest protein atom to the ligand, picked to avoid pbc problems during the simulation

POINTS.description: 6 values defining x, y, and z of the 2 points used to construct the line

SQUARED-ROOT.description: Used to initialize the creation of the alignment variable

lp.description: the position along the funnel line

ld.description: the distance from the funnel line

FUNNEL_PS.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                 LIGAND - This MUST be a single atom, normally the COM of the ligand. 
                          For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef 
                          Group 
                 ANCHOR - Closest protein atom to the ligand, picked to avoid pbc 
                          problems during the simulation. For more information on how to 
                          specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              REFERENCE - a file in pdb format containing the structure you would 
                          like to align. 
                 POINTS - 6 values defining x, y, and z of the 2 points used to 
                          construct the line. The order should be A_x,A_y,A_z,B_x,B_y,B_z. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
           SQUARED-ROOT - ( default=off ) Used to initialize the creation of the 
                          alignment variable

FUSIONPOREEXPANSIONP.description: A CV for inducing the expansion of a fusion pore from a nucleated fusion pore.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

UMEMBRANE.description: all the beads of the upper membrane

LMEMBRANE.description: all the beads of the lower membrane

TAILS.description: all the tail beads of the system

WATERS.description: all the water beads of the system

PHOSPHATEOXYGENS.description: all the lipid phosphateoxygens beads of the system

NSMEM.description: the number of slices of the membrane fusion cylinder

DSMEM.description: thickness of the slices of the membrane fusion cylinder

HMEM.description: parameter of the step function (x,h) for the membrane fusion

D.description: horizontal layer thickness, it depends on the Z separation of the membranes

H.description: parameter of the step function (x,h) for the fusion pore expansion

RMAX.description: to avoid effects of membrane undulations in large membranes (more than 256 lipids)

R0.description: normalization constant that makes 0 the initial value of the CV

XCYL.description: X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this will be calculated

YCYL.description: X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this will be calculated

value.description: the value of the CV

FUSIONPOREEXPANSIONP.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

              UMEMBRANE - all the beads of the upper membrane.. For more information 
                          on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
              LMEMBRANE - all the beads of the lower membrane.. For more information 
                          on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                  TAILS - all the tail beads of the system.. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 WATERS - all the water beads of the system.. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
       PHOSPHATEOXYGENS - all the lipid phosphateoxygens beads of the system.. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  NSMEM - the number of slices of the membrane fusion cylinder. 
                      D - horizontal layer thickness, it depends on the Z separation 
                          of the membranes. 
                     R0 - normalization constant that makes 0 the initial value of 
                          the CV. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                  DSMEM - ( default=0.1 ) thickness of the slices of the membrane 
                          fusion cylinder. 
                   HMEM - ( default=0.25 ) parameter of the step function (x,h) for 
                          the membrane fusion. 
                     VO - ( default=0.076879 ) beads' molecular volume. 
                      H - ( default=0.1 ) parameter of the step function (x,h) for 
                          the fusion pore expansion. 
                   RMAX - ( default=2.5 ) to avoid effects of membrane undulations in 
                          large membranes (more than 256 lipids). 
                   XCYL - X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this 
                          will be calculated. 
                   YCYL - X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this 
                          will be calculated.

FUSIONPORENUCLEATIONP.description: A CV for inducing the nucleation of the fusion pore from a hemifusion stalk.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

UMEMBRANE.description: all the beads of the upper membrane

LMEMBRANE.description: all the beads of the lower membrane

TAILS.description: all the tail beads of the system

WATERS.description: all the water beads of the system

PHOSPHATEOXYGENS.description: all the lipid phosphateoxygens beads of the system

NSMEM.description: the number of slices of the membrane fusion cylinder

DSMEM.description: thickness of the slices of the membrane fusion cylinder

HMEM.description: parameter of the step function (x,h) for the membrane fusion

NS.description: the number of slices of the membrane-spanning cylinder in such a way that when the bilayers are flat and parallel the CV is equal to 0

DS.description: thickness of the slices of the membrane-spanning cylinder

HCH.description: parameter of the step function (x,h) for the CV

RCYL.description: the radius of the membrane-spanning cylinder

ONEOVERS2C2CUTOFF.description: cut off large values for the derivative of the atan2 function to avoid violate energy

XCYL.description: X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this will be calculated

YCYL.description: X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this will be calculated

value.description: the value of the CV

FUSIONPORENUCLEATIONP.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

              UMEMBRANE - all the beads of the upper membrane.. For more information 
                          on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
              LMEMBRANE - all the beads of the lower membrane.. For more information 
                          on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                  TAILS - all the tail beads of the system.. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 WATERS - all the water beads of the system.. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
       PHOSPHATEOXYGENS - all the lipid phosphateoxygens beads of the system.. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  NSMEM - the number of slices of the membrane fusion cylinder. 
                     NS - the number of slices of the membrane-spanning cylinder in 
                          such a way that when the bilayers are flat and parallel the CV 
                          is equal to 0.2. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                  DSMEM - ( default=0.1 ) thickness of the slices of the membrane 
                          fusion cylinder. 
                   HMEM - ( default=0.25 ) parameter of the step function (x,h) for 
                          the membrane fusion. 
                     DS - ( default=0.25 ) thickness of the slices of the 
                          membrane-spanning cylinder. 
                    HCH - ( default=0.25 ) parameter of the step function (x,h) for 
                          the CV. 
                   RCYL - ( default=0.8 ) the radius of the membrane-spanning 
                          cylinder. 
                   ZETA - ( default=0.75 ) parameter of the switch function (x,). 
      ONEOVERS2C2CUTOFF - ( default=500 ) cut off large values for the derivative of 
                          the atan2 function to avoid violate energy. 
                   XCYL - X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this 
                          will be calculated. 
                   YCYL - X coordinate of the fixed cylinder, if not present this 
                          will be calculated.

GATHER_REPLICAS.description: Create a vector that contains the copies of the input quantities from all replicas

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the argument from the various replicas that you would like to gather

rep.description: the input arguments for each of the replicas

GATHER_REPLICAS.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the argument from the various replicas that you would like 
                          to gather

GEOMETRIC_PATH.description: Distance along and from a path calculated using geometric formulas

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the matrix that contains the vectors of displacements from each frame in the path

METRIC.description: the method to use for computing the displacement vectors between the reference frames

METRIC_COMPONENT.description: if the final action in your metric contains multiple components this keyword is used to specify the component that should be used

REFERENCE.description: labels for actions that contain reference coordinates for each point on the path

PROPERTY.description: the label of a value that contains the coordinates we are projecting these points onto

z.description: the distance from the path

GEOMETRIC_PATH.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the matrix that contains the vectors of 
                          displacements from each frame in the path 
                 METRIC - the method to use for computing the displacement vectors 
                          between the reference frames 
       METRIC_COMPONENT - if the final action in your metric contains multiple 
                          components this keyword is used to specify the component that should 
                          be used 
              REFERENCE - labels for actions that contain reference coordinates for 
                          each point on the path 
               PROPERTY - the label of a value that contains the coordinates we are 
                          projecting these points onto 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize

GET.description: Get data from PLUMED for another code

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

ARG.description: the label of the value that you would like to GET

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the quantities of interest should be stored

TYPE.description: what do you want to collect for the value can be derivative/force

GET.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which the quantities of 
                          interest should be stored 
                   TYPE - ( default=value ) what do you want to collect for the value 
                          can be derivative/force 
                    ARG - the label of the value that you would like to GET

GET_VOLUME_ELEMENT.description: Get the volume element from the input grid

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the label for function on the grid that you need the volume element for

value.description: the volume element

GET_VOLUME_ELEMENT.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the label for function on the grid that you need the volume 
                          element for

GHBFIX.description: Calculate the GHBFIX interaction energy between GROUPA and GROUPB

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

SERIAL.description: Perform the calculation in serial - for debug purpose

PAIR.description: Pair only 1st element of the 1st group with 1st element in the second, etc

NLIST.description: Use a neighbor list to speed up the calculation

NL_CUTOFF.description: The cutoff for the neighbor list

NL_STRIDE.description: The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the neighbor list

GROUPA.description: First list of atoms

GROUPB.description: Second list of atoms (if empty, N*(N-1)/2 pairs in GROUPA are counted)

ENERGY_UNITS.description: the value of ENERGY_UNITS in the switching function

TYPES.description: the value of TYPES in the switching function

PARAMS.description: the value of PARAMS in the switching function

D_MAX.description: the value of D_MAX in the switching function

D_0.description: the value of D_0 in the switching function

C.description: the value of C in the switching function

value.description: the GHBFIX interaction energy between the atoms in GROUPA and GROUPB

GHBFIX.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                 GROUPA - First list of atoms. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPB - Second list of atoms (if empty, N*(N-1)/2 pairs in GROUPA 
                          are counted). For more information on how to specify lists of 
                          atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  TYPES - the value of TYPES in the switching function 
                 PARAMS - the value of PARAMS in the switching function 
                  D_MAX - the value of D_MAX in the switching function 
                    D_0 - the value of D_0 in the switching function 
                      C - the value of C in the switching function 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
                   PAIR - ( default=off ) Pair only 1st element of the 1st group with 
                          1st element in the second, etc 
                  NLIST - ( default=off ) Use a neighbor list to speed up the 
                          calculation 
              NL_CUTOFF - The cutoff for the neighbor list 
              NL_STRIDE - The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the 
                          neighbor list 
           ENERGY_UNITS - the value of ENERGY_UNITS in the switching function

GHOST.description: Calculate the absolute position of a ghost atom with fixed coordinates in the local reference frame formed by three atoms.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

ATOMS.description: the list of atoms which are involved the virtual atom's definition

COORDINATES.description: coordinates of the ghost atom in the local reference frame

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

GHOST.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the list of atoms which are involved the virtual atom's 
                          definition. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see 
                          ef Group 
            COORDINATES - coordinates of the ghost atom in the local reference frame. 
                          For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef 
                          Group 

The following options are available

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances

GPATH.description: Distance along and from a path calculated using geometric formulas

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

REFERENCE.description: a pdb file containing the set of reference configurations

TYPE.description: the manner in which distances are calculated

ARG.description: the list of arguments you would like to use in your definition of the path

COEFFICIENTS.description: the coefficients of the displacements along each argument that should be used when calculating the euclidean distance

NOSPATH.description: do not calculate the spath CV

NOZPATH.description: do not calculate the zpath CV

PROPERTY.description: read in path coordinates by finding option with this label in remark of pdb frames

z.description: the distance from the path

GPATH.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

              REFERENCE - a pdb file containing the set of reference configurations 
                   TYPE - ( default=OPTIMAL-FAST ) the manner in which distances are 
                          calculated. More information on the different metrics that are 
                          available in PLUMED can be found in the section of the manual on ef 
                          dists 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                NOSPATH - ( default=off ) do not calculate the spath CV 
                NOZPATH - ( default=off ) do not calculate the zpath CV 
                  GPATH - ( default=off ) calculate the trigonometric path 
                    ARG - the list of arguments you would like to use in your 
                          definition of the path 
           COEFFICIENTS - the coefficients of the displacements along each argument 
                          that should be used when calculating the euclidean distance 
               PROPERTY - read in path coordinates by finding option with this label 
                          in remark of pdb frames

GPROPERTYMAP.description: Property maps but with a more flexible framework for the distance metric being used.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

REFERENCE.description: a pdb file containing the set of reference configurations

TYPE.description: the manner in which distances are calculated

ARG.description: the list of arguments you would like to use in your definition of the path

COEFFICIENTS.description: the coefficients of the displacements along each argument that should be used when calculating the euclidean distance

NOSPATH.description: do not calculate the spath CV

NOZPATH.description: do not calculate the zpath CV

PROPERTY.description: the property to be used in the index

LAMBDA.description: the lambda parameter is needed for smoothing, is in the units of plumed

gspath.description: the position along the path calculated using the geometric formula

gzpath.description: the distance from the path calculated using the geometric formula

spath.description: the position along the path calculated

zpath.description: the distance from the path calculated

GPROPERTYMAP.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

              REFERENCE - a pdb file containing the set of reference configurations 
                   TYPE - ( default=OPTIMAL-FAST ) the manner in which distances are 
                          calculated. More information on the different metrics that are 
                          available in PLUMED can be found in the section of the manual on ef 
                          dists 
                 LAMBDA - the lambda parameter is needed for smoothing, is in the 
                          units of plumed 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                NOSPATH - ( default=off ) do not calculate the spath CV 
                NOZPATH - ( default=off ) do not calculate the zpath CV 
                  GPATH - ( default=off ) calculate the trigonometric path 
                    ARG - the list of arguments you would like to use in your 
                          definition of the path 
           COEFFICIENTS - the coefficients of the displacements along each argument 
                          that should be used when calculating the euclidean distance 
               PROPERTY - the property to be used in the index. This should be in the 
                          REMARK of the reference

GRADIENT.description: Calculate the gradient of an input grid

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ORIGIN.description: we will use the position of this atom as the origin in our calculation

NBINS.description: number of bins to use in each direction for the calculation of the gradient

DIR.description: the directions in which we are calculating the graident

SIGMA.description: the width of the function to be used for kernel density estimation

KERNEL.description: the type of kernel function to be used in the grids

ATOMS.description: calculate the gradient of these atoms

value.description: the desired gradient

GRADIENT.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 ORIGIN - we will use the position of this atom as the origin in our 
                          calculation 
                  NBINS - number of bins to use in each direction for the calculation 
                          of the gradient 
                    DIR - ( default=xyz ) the directions in which we are calculating 
                          the graident. Should be x, y, z, xy, xz, yz or xyz 
                  SIGMA - the width of the function to be used for kernel density 
                          estimation 
                 KERNEL - ( default=gaussian-bin ) the type of kernel function to be 
                          used in the grids 
                  ATOMS - calculate the gradient of these atoms

GROUP.description: Define a group of atoms so that a particular list of atoms can be referenced with a single label in definitions of CVs or virtual atoms.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

ATOMS.description: the numerical indexes for the set of atoms in the group

REMOVE.description: remove these atoms from the list

UNIQUE.description: sort atoms and remove duplicated ones

NDX_FILE.description: the name of index file (gromacs syntax)

NDX_GROUP.description: the name of the group to be imported (gromacs syntax) - first group found is used by default

GROUP.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the numerical indexes for the set of atoms in the group. 
                          For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef 
                          Group 
                 REMOVE - remove these atoms from the list. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following options are available

                   SORT - ( default=off ) sort the resulting list 
                 UNIQUE - ( default=off ) sort atoms and remove duplicated ones 
               NDX_FILE - the name of index file (gromacs syntax) 
              NDX_GROUP - the name of the group to be imported (gromacs syntax) - 
                          first group found is used by default

GSYMFUNC_THREEBODY.description: Calculate functions of the coordinates of the coordinates of all pairs of bonds in the first coordination sphere of an atom

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: three matrices containing the bond vectors of interest

WEIGHT.description: the matrix that contains the weights that should be used for each connection

FUNCTION.description: the parameters of the function you would like to compute

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

.#!custom.description: the names of the output components for this action depend on the actions input file see the example inputs below for details

GSYMFUNC_THREEBODY.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - three matrices containing the bond vectors of interest 
                 WEIGHT - the matrix that contains the weights that should be used 
                          for each connection 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
               FUNCTION - the parameters of the function you would like to compute. 
                          You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. FUNCTION1, 
                          FUNCTION2, FUNCTION3...

GYRATION.description: Calculate the radius of gyration, or other properties related to it.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ATOMS.description: the group of atoms that you are calculating the Gyration Tensor for

TYPE.description: The type of calculation relative to the Gyration Tensor you want to perform

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

WEIGHTS.description: what weights should be used when calculating the center

PHASES.description: use trigonometric phases when computing position of center of mass

MASS_WEIGHTED.description: set the masses of all the atoms equal to one

UNORMALIZED.description: do not divide by the sum of the weights

value.description: the radius that was computed from the weights

GYRATION.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the group of atoms that you are calculating the Gyration 
                          Tensor for. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms 
                          see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                   TYPE - ( default=RADIUS ) The type of calculation relative to the 
                          Gyration Tensor you want to perform 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 PHASES - ( default=off ) use trigonometric phases when computing 
                          position of center of mass 
                   MASS - ( default=off ) calculate the center of mass 
          MASS_WEIGHTED - ( default=off ) set the masses of all the atoms equal to 
                          one 
            UNORMALIZED - ( default=off ) do not divide by the sum of the weights 
                WEIGHTS - what weights should be used when calculating the center. If 
                          this keyword is not present the geometric center is computed. If 
                          WEIGHTS=@Masses is used the center of mass is computed. If WEIGHTS=@charges 
                          the center of charge is computed. If the label of an action is 
                          provided PLUMED assumes that that action calculates a list of 
                          symmetry functions that can be used as weights. Lastly, an explicit 
                          list of numbers to use as weights can be provided

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

The following arguments are compulsory:

In addition you may use the following options:

            UNORMALIZED - ( default=off ) do not divide by the sum of the weights 
                WEIGHTS - what weights should be used when calculating the center. If

                          WEIGHTS=@Masses is used the center of mass is computed. If WEIGHTS=@charges

HBOND_MATRIX.description: Adjacency matrix in which two atoms are adjacent if there is a hydrogen bond between them.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

MASK.description: a vector that is used to used to determine which rows of the adjancency matrix to compute

GROUP.description: the atoms for which you would like to calculate the adjacency matrix

GROUPA.description: when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along with the keyword GROUPB

GROUPB.description: when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along with the keyword GROUPA

ATOMS.description: the atoms for which you would like to calculate the adjacency matrix

COMPONENTS.description: also calculate the components of the vector connecting the atoms in the contact matrix

NOPBC.description: don't use pbc

NL_CUTOFF.description: The cutoff for the neighbor list

NL_STRIDE.description: The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the neighbor list

DONORS.description: The list of atoms which can donate a hydrogen bond

ACCEPTORS.description: The list of atoms which can accept a hydrogen bond

HYDROGENS.description: The list of atoms that can form the bridge between the two interesting parts of the structure

SWITCH.description: The switchingfunction that specifies how close a pair of atoms must be together for there to be a hydrogen bond between them

HSWITCH.description: The switchingfunction that specifies how close the hydrogen must be to the donor atom of the hydrogen bond for it to be considered a hydrogen bond

ASWITCH.description: A switchingfunction that is used to specify what the angle between the vector connecting the donor atom to the acceptor atom and the vector connecting the donor atom to the hydrogen must be in order for it considered to be a hydrogen bond

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

w.description: a matrix containing the weights for the bonds between each pair of atoms

x.description: the projection of the bond on the x axis

y.description: the projection of the bond on the y axis

z.description: the projection of the bond on the z axis

value.description: a matrix containing the weights for the bonds between each pair of atoms

HBOND_MATRIX.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  GROUP - the atoms for which you would like to calculate the 
                          adjacency matrix. For more information on how to specify lists of 
                          atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPA - when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two 
                          sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along 
                          with the keyword GROUPB. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPB - when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two 
                          sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along 
                          with the keyword GROUPA. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group 
                  ATOMS - the atoms for which you would like to calculate the 
                          adjacency matrix. This is a depracated syntax that is equivalent to 
                          GROUP. You are strongly recommened to use GROUP instead of ATOMS. 
                 DONORS - The list of atoms which can donate a hydrogen bond 
              ACCEPTORS - The list of atoms which can accept a hydrogen bond 
              HYDROGENS - The list of atoms that can form the bridge between the two 
                          interesting parts of the structure.. For more information on how to 
                          specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              NL_CUTOFF - ( default=0.0 ) The cutoff for the neighbor list. A value 
                          of 0 means we are not using a neighbor list 
              NL_STRIDE - ( default=1 ) The frequency with which we are updating the 
                          atoms in the neighbor list 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
             COMPONENTS - ( default=off ) also calculate the components of the vector 
                          connecting the atoms in the contact matrix 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) don't use pbc 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                   MASK - a vector that is used to used to determine which rows of 
                          the adjancency matrix to compute 
                 SWITCH - The switchingfunction that specifies how close a pair of 
                          atoms must be together for there to be a hydrogen bond between 
                          them. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. 
                          SWITCH1, SWITCH2, SWITCH3... 
                HSWITCH - The switchingfunction that specifies how close the hydrogen 
                          must be to the donor atom of the hydrogen bond for it to be 
                          considered a hydrogen bond. You can use multiple instances of this 
                          keyword i.e. HSWITCH1, HSWITCH2, HSWITCH3... 
                ASWITCH - A switchingfunction that is used to specify what the angle 
                          between the vector connecting the donor atom to the acceptor atom 
                          and the vector connecting the donor atom to the hydrogen must 
                          be in order for it considered to be a hydrogen bond. You can 
                          use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. ASWITCH1, ASWITCH2, 
                          ASWITCH3...

HBPAMM_MATRIX.description: Adjacency matrix in which two electronegative atoms are adjacent if they are hydrogen bonded

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

MASK.description: a vector that is used to used to determine which rows of the adjancency matrix to compute

GROUP.description: the atoms for which you would like to calculate the adjacency matrix

GROUPA.description: when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along with the keyword GROUPB

GROUPB.description: when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along with the keyword GROUPA

ATOMS.description: the atoms for which you would like to calculate the adjacency matrix

COMPONENTS.description: also calculate the components of the vector connecting the atoms in the contact matrix

NOPBC.description: don't use pbc

NL_CUTOFF.description: The cutoff for the neighbor list

NL_STRIDE.description: The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the neighbor list

GROUPC.description: a group of atoms that must be summed over when calculating each element of the adjacency matrix

ORDER.description: the order in which the groups are specified in the input

CLUSTERS.description: the name of the file that contains the definitions of all the kernels for PAMM

REGULARISE.description: don't allow the denominator to be smaller then this value

GAUSS_CUTOFF.description: the cutoff at which to stop evaluating the kernel function is set equal to sqrt(2*x)*(max(adc)+cov(adc))

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

w.description: a matrix containing the weights for the bonds between each pair of atoms

x.description: the projection of the bond on the x axis

y.description: the projection of the bond on the y axis

z.description: the projection of the bond on the z axis

value.description: a matrix containing the weights for the bonds between each pair of atoms

HBPAMM_MATRIX.help:

                  GROUP - the atoms for which you would like to calculate the 
                          adjacency matrix. For more information on how to specify lists of 
                          atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPA - when you are calculating the adjacency matrix between two 
                          sets of atoms this keyword is used to specify the atoms along 
                          with the keyword GROUPB. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group

                          with the keyword GROUPA. For more information on how to specify 
                          lists of atoms see ef Group

                          each element of the adjacency matrix. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group

                          of 0 means we are not using a neighbor list

                          atoms in the neighbor list 
                  ORDER - ( default=dah ) the order in which the groups are specified 
                          in the input. Can be dah (donor/acceptor/hydrogens), adh 
                          (acceptor/donor/hydrogens) or hda (hydrogens/donor/acceptors 
               CLUSTERS - the name of the file that contains the definitions of all 
                          the kernels for PAMM

                          then this value

                          parallelize

                          connecting the atoms in the contact matrix 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) don't use pbc 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                   MASK - a vector that is used to used to determine which rows of 
                          the adjancency matrix to compute
