SPECIES.description: the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments

SPECIESA.description: the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

SPECIESB.description: the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being calculated

NN.description: The n parameter of the switching function

MM.description: The m parameter of the switching function; 0 implies 2*NN

D_0.description: The d_0 parameter of the switching function

R_0.description: The r_0 parameter of the switching function

SWITCH.description: the switching function that it used in the construction of the contact matrix

MASK.description: the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows of the matrix are computed

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are less than a certain target value

MORE_THAN.description: calculate the number of variables that are more than a certain target value

BETWEEN.description: calculate the number of values that are within a certain range

HIGHEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the highest of these variables

HISTOGRAM.description: calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of values

LOWEST.description: this flag allows you to recover the lowest of these variables

SUM.description: calculate the sum of all the quantities

MEAN.description: calculate the mean of all the quantities

LOWMEM.description: Including this keyword in the input to this action makes no difference to the calculation performed it was used in older versions of PLUMED and is provided here for back compatibility only

VMEAN.description: calculate the norm of the mean vector

VSUM.description: calculate the norm of the sum of all the vectors

lessthan.description: the number of colvars that have a value less than a threshold

morethan.description: the number of colvars that have a value more than a threshold

altmin.description: the minimum value of the cv

between.description: the number of colvars that have a value that lies in a particular interval

_vmean.description: the norm of the mean vector

_vsum.description: the norm of the mean vector

value.description: the norms of the vectors of spherical harmonic coefficients

Q4.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                SPECIES - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated and the atoms that can be in the environments 
               SPECIESA - the list of atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESB, 
                          which specifies the atoms that are in the environment. 
               SPECIESB - the list of atoms that can be in the environments of each 
                          of the atoms for which the symmetry function is being 
                          calculated. This keyword must be used in conjunction with SPECIESA, 
                          which specifies the atoms for which the symmetry function is 
                          being calculated. 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                     NN - ( default=6 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=0 ) The m parameter of the switching function; 0 
                          implies 2*NN 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                HIGHEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the highest 
                          of these variables. 
                 LOWEST - ( default=off ) this flag allows you to recover the lowest 
                          of these variables. 
                    SUM - ( default=off ) calculate the sum of all the quantities. 
                   MEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the mean of all the quantities. 
                  VMEAN - ( default=off ) calculate the norm of the mean vector. 
                   VSUM - ( default=off ) calculate the norm of the sum of all the 
                          vectors 
                 SWITCH - the switching function that it used in the construction of 
                          the contact matrix 
                   MASK - the label for a vector that is used to determine which rows 
                          of the matrix are computed 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are less than a 
                          certain target value. 
              MORE_THAN - calculate the number of variables that are more than a 
                          certain target value. 
                ALT_MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MIN - calculate the minimum value. 
                    MAX - calculate the maximum value. 
                BETWEEN - calculate the number of values that are within a certain 
                          range. These quantities are calculated using kernel density 
                          estimation as described on ef histogrambead.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. BETWEEN1, BETWEEN2, BETWEEN3... 
              HISTOGRAM - calculate a discretized histogram of the distribution of 
                          values. This shortcut allows you to calculates NBIN quantites like 
                          BETWEEN.

QUATERNION_BOND_PRODUCT_MATRIX.description: Calculate the product between a matrix of quaternions and the bonds connecting molecules

QUATERNION_BOND_PRODUCT_MATRIX.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - this action takes 8 arguments. The first four should be the 
                          w,i,j and k components of a quaternion vector. The second four 
                          should be contact matrix and the matrices should be the x, y and z 
                          components of the bond vectors 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

RDC.description: Calculates the (Residual) Dipolar Coupling between two atoms.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the values from which the function is calculated

REWEIGHT.description: simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy

AVERAGING.description: Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean

LIKELIHOOD.description: the likelihood for the GENERIC metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN

DFTILDE.description: fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve ftilde

SCALEDATA.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling factor common to all values and replicas

SCALE0.description: initial value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MIN.description: minimum value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MAX.description: maximum value of the scaling factor

DSCALE.description: maximum MC move of the scaling factor

ADDOFFSET.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset common to all values and replicas

DOFFSET.description: maximum MC move of the offset

REGRES_ZERO.description: stride for regression with zero offset

SIGMA0.description: initial value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MIN.description: minimum value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MAX.description: maximum value of the uncertainty parameter

DSIGMA.description: maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter

OPTSIGMAMEAN.description: Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma mean, or to estimate it on the fly

SIGMA_MEAN0.description: starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate

SIGMA_MAX_STEPS.description: Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the SIGMA_MAX value is used

TEMP.description: the system temperature - this is only needed if code doesn't pass the temperature to plumed

STATUS_FILE.description: write a file with all the data useful for restart/continuation of Metainference

FMT.description: specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the number of digits in regtests)

WRITE_STRIDE.description: write the status to a file every N steps, this can be used for restart/continuation

NSELECT.description: range of values for selector [0, N-1]

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

ATOMS.description: the couple of atoms involved in each of the bonds for which you wish to calculate the RDC

GYROM.description: Add the product of the gyromagnetic constants for the bond

SCALE.description: Add the scaling factor to take into account concentration and other effects

SVD.description: Set to TRUE if you want to back calculate using Single Value Decomposition (need GSL at compilation time)

COUPLING.description: Add an experimental value for each coupling (needed by SVD and useful for STATS)

acceptFT.description: MC acceptance for general metainference f tilde value

biasDer.description: derivatives with respect to the bias

RDC.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the couple of atoms involved in each of the bonds for which 
                          you wish to calculate the RDC. Keywords like ATOMS1, ATOMS2, 
                          ATOMS3,... should be listed and one dipolar coupling will be 
                          calculated for each ATOMS keyword you specify.. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. ATOMS1, ATOMS2, ATOMS3... 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              NOISETYPE - ( default=MGAUSS ) functional form of the noise 
                          (GAUSS,MGAUSS,OUTLIERS,MOUTLIERS,GENERIC) 
             LIKELIHOOD - ( default=GAUSS ) the likelihood for the GENERIC 
                          metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN 
                DFTILDE - ( default=0.1 ) fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve 
                          ftilde 
                 SCALE0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the scaling factor 
            SCALE_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                OFFSET0 - ( default=0.0 ) initial value of the offset 
           OFFSET_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                 SIGMA0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MIN - ( default=0.0 ) minimum value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MAX - ( default=10. ) maximum value of the uncertainty parameter 
           OPTSIGMAMEAN - ( default=NONE ) Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma 
                          mean, or to estimate it on the fly 
           WRITE_STRIDE - ( default=10000 ) write the status to a file every N steps, 
                          this can be used for restart/continuation 
                  GYROM - ( default=1. ) Add the product of the gyromagnetic 
                          constants for the bond. 
                  SCALE - ( default=1. ) Add the scaling factor to take into account 
                          concentration and other effects. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                DOSCORE - ( default=off ) activate metainference 
             NOENSEMBLE - ( default=off ) don't perform any replica-averaging 
               REWEIGHT - ( default=off ) simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy 
              SCALEDATA - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling 
                          factor common to all values and replicas 
              ADDOFFSET - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset 
                          common to all values and replicas 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                    SVD - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to back calculate 
                          using Single Value Decomposition (need GSL at compilation time). 
                    ARG - the labels of the values from which the function is 
                          calculated 
              AVERAGING - Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean 
              SCALE_MIN - minimum value of the scaling factor 
              SCALE_MAX - maximum value of the scaling factor 
                 DSCALE - maximum MC move of the scaling factor 
             OFFSET_MIN - minimum value of the offset 
             OFFSET_MAX - maximum value of the offset 
                DOFFSET - maximum MC move of the offset 
            REGRES_ZERO - stride for regression with zero offset 
                 DSIGMA - maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter 
            SIGMA_MEAN0 - starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate 
        SIGMA_MAX_STEPS - Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the 
                          SIGMA_MAX value is used 
                   TEMP - the system temperature - this is only needed if code 
                          doesn't pass the temperature to plumed 
               MC_STEPS - number of MC steps 
           MC_CHUNKSIZE - MC chunksize 
            STATUS_FILE - write a file with all the data useful for 
                          restart/continuation of Metainference 
                    FMT - specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the 
                          number of digits in regtests) 
               SELECTOR - name of selector 
                NSELECT - range of values for selector [0, N-1] 
                RESTART - allows per-action setting of restart (YES/NO/AUTO) 
               COUPLING - Add an experimental value for each coupling (needed by SVD 
                          and useful for STATS).. You can use multiple instances of this 
                          keyword i.e. COUPLING1, COUPLING2, COUPLING3...

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

GROUP.description: the atoms that are being used to calculate the RDF

ATOMS.description: the atoms that are being used to calculate the RDF

GROUPA.description: the atoms that you would like to compute the RDF about

GROUPB.description: the atoms that you would like to to use when computing the RDF around the atoms that were specified with GROUPA

GRID_BIN.description: the number of bins to use when computing the RDF

KERNEL.description: the type of kernel to use for computing the histograms for the RDF

CUTOFF.description: the cutoff at which to stop evaluating the kernel functions is set equal to sqrt(2*x)*bandwidth in each direction where x is this number

MAXR.description: the maximum distance to use for the rdf

BANDWIDTH.description: the bandwidths for kernel density esimtation

CLEAR.description: the frequency with which to clear the estimate of the rdf

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which to compute the rdf and accumulate averages

DENSITY.description: the reference density to use when normalizing the RDF

REFERENCE.description: this is the label of the reference objects

value.description: the radial distribution function

RDF.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  GROUP - the atoms that are being used to calculate the RDF. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                  ATOMS - the atoms that are being used to calculate the RDF. For 
                          more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
                 GROUPA - the atoms that you would like to compute the RDF about. 
                          Must be used with GROUPB. 
                 GROUPB - the atoms that you would like to to use when computing the 
                          RDF around the atoms that were specified with GROUPA 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

               GRID_BIN - the number of bins to use when computing the RDF 
                 KERNEL - ( default=GAUSSIAN ) the type of kernel to use for 
                          computing the histograms for the RDF 
                 CUTOFF - ( default=6.25 ) the cutoff at which to stop evaluating the 
                          kernel functions is set equal to sqrt(2*x)*bandwidth in each 
                          direction where x is this number 
                   MAXR - the maximum distance to use for the rdf 
              BANDWIDTH - the bandwidths for kernel density esimtation 
                  CLEAR - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which to clear the 
                          estimate of the rdf. Set equal to 0 if you want to compute an rdf 
                          over the whole trajectory 
                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which to compute the rdf 
                          and accumulate averages 
                DENSITY - the reference density to use when normalizing the RDF

READ.description: Read quantities from a colvar file.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the file should be read

EVERY.description: only read every nth line of the colvar file

VALUES.description: the values to read from the file

FILE.description: the name of the file from which to read these quantities

IGNORE_TIME.description: ignore the time in the colvar file

IGNORE_FORCES.description: use this flag if the forces added by any bias can be safely ignored

UPDATE_FROM.description: Only update this action from this time

UPDATE_UNTIL.description: Only update this action until this time

.#!custom.description: the names of the output components for this action depend on the actions input file see the example inputs below for details

READ.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which the file should be 
                          read. 
                  EVERY - ( default=1 ) only read every nth line of the colvar file. 
                          This should be used if the colvar was written more frequently 
                          than the trajectory. 
                 VALUES - the values to read from the file 
                   FILE - the name of the file from which to read these quantities 

In addition you may use the following options: 

            IGNORE_TIME - ( default=off ) ignore the time in the colvar file. When 
                          this flag is not present read will be quite strict about the 
                          start time of the simulation and the stride between frames 
          IGNORE_FORCES - ( default=off ) use this flag if the forces added by any 
                          bias can be safely ignored. As an example forces can be safely 
                          ignored if you are doing post processing that does not involve 
                          outputting forces 
            UPDATE_FROM - Only update this action from this time 
           UPDATE_UNTIL - Only update this action until this time

READMASSCHARGE.description: Set the masses and charges from an input PDB file.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

FILE.description: input file that contains the masses and charges that should be used

PDBFILE.description: a pdb file that contains the masses and charges of the atoms in the beta and occupancy columns

mass.description: the masses of the atoms in the system

charges.description: the masses of the atoms in the system

READMASSCHARGE.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                PDBFILE - a pdb file that contains the masses and charges of the 
                          atoms in the beta and occupancy columns 
                   FILE - input file that contains the masses and charges that should 
                          be used

REFERENCE_GRID.description: Setup a constant grid by either reading values from a file or definining a function in input

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

FUNC.description: the function to compute on the grid

GRID_MIN.description: the lower bounds for the grid

GRID_MAX.description: the upper bounds for the grid

PERIODIC.description: are the grid directions periodic

GRID_BIN.description: the number of bins for the grid

GRID_SPACING.description: the approximate grid spacing (to be used as an alternative or together with GRID_BIN)

VAR.description: the names to give each of the grid directions in the function

FILE.description: the name of the file that contains the reference data

VALUE.description: the name of the value that should be read from the grid

value.description: the constant function on the grid that was specified in input

REFERENCE_GRID.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

               GRID_MIN - ( default=auto ) the lower bounds for the grid 
               GRID_MAX - ( default=auto ) the upper bounds for the grid 
               PERIODIC - are the grid directions periodic 
                   FILE - the name of the file that contains the reference data 
                  VALUE - the name of the value that should be read from the grid 
                   FUNC - the function to compute on the grid 
               GRID_BIN - the number of bins for the grid 
           GRID_SPACING - the approximate grid spacing (to be used as an alternative 
                          or together with GRID_BIN) 
                    VAR - the names to give each of the grid directions in the 
                          function. If you have up to three grid coordinates in your function 
                          you can use x, y and z to refer to them. Otherwise you must use 
                          this flag to give your variables names.

REPARAMETERIZE_PATH.description: Take an input path with frames that are not equally spaced and make the frames equally spaced

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

ARG.description: the labels of the matrix that contains the vectors of displacements from each frame in the path

METRIC.description: the method to use for computing the displacement vectors between the reference frames

METRIC_COMPONENT.description: if the final action in your metric contains multiple components this keyword is used to specify the component that should be used

REFERENCE.description: labels for actions that contain reference coordinates for each point on the path

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which to reparameterize the path

FIXED.description: the frames in the path to fix

MAXCYLES.description: number of cycles of the algorithm to run

TOL.description: the tolerance to use for the path reparameterization algorithm

DISPLACE_FRAMES.description: label of an action that tells us how to displace the frames

REPARAMETERIZE_PATH.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the matrix that contains the vectors of 
                          displacements from each frame in the path 
                 METRIC - the method to use for computing the displacement vectors 
                          between the reference frames 
       METRIC_COMPONENT - if the final action in your metric contains multiple 
                          components this keyword is used to specify the component that should 
                          be used 
              REFERENCE - labels for actions that contain reference coordinates for 
                          each point on the path 
                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which to reparameterize 
                          the path 
                  FIXED - ( default=0 ) the frames in the path to fix 
               MAXCYLES - ( default=100 ) number of cycles of the algorithm to run 
                    TOL - ( default=1E-4 ) the tolerance to use for the path 
                          reparameterization algorithm 
        DISPLACE_FRAMES - label of an action that tells us how to displace the 
                          frames. These displacements are applied before running the 
                          reparameterization algorith

RESCALE.description: Scales the value of an another action, being a Collective Variable or a Bias.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the forces due to the bias should be calculated

TEMP.description: temperature

SELECTOR.description: name of the SELECTOR used for rescaling

NBIN.description: number of bins for gamma grid

NOT_SHARED.description: list of arguments (from 1 to N) not summed across replicas

NOT_RESCALED.description: these last N arguments will not be scaled

PACE.description: Pace for adding bias, in MC stride unit

bias.description: the instantaneous value of the bias potential

RESCALE.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of the scalars on which the bias will act 
                   TEMP - temperature 
               SELECTOR - name of the SELECTOR used for rescaling 
            MAX_RESCALE - maximum values for rescaling 
                   NBIN - number of bins for gamma grid 
                     W0 - initial bias height 
             BIASFACTOR - bias factor 
                BSTRIDE - stride for writing bias 
                  BFILE - file name for bias 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
             NOT_SHARED - list of arguments (from 1 to N) not summed across replicas 
           NOT_RESCALED - these last N arguments will not be scaled 
               MC_STEPS - number of MC steps 
              MC_STRIDE - MC stride 
                   PACE - Pace for adding bias, in MC stride unit

RESET_CELL.description: This action is used to rotate the full cell

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which molecules are reassembled

TYPE.description: the manner in which the cell is reset

RESET_CELL.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                 STRIDE - ( default=1 ) the frequency with which molecules are 
                          reassembled. Unless you are completely certain about what you are doing 
                          leave this set equal to 1! 
                   TYPE - ( default=TRIANGULAR ) the manner in which the cell is 
                          reset

NO.description: switch off restart - can be used to override the behavior of the MD engine

RESTART.help:
The following options are available

                     NO - ( default=off ) switch off restart - can be used to 
                          override the behavior of the MD engine

RESTRAINT.description: Adds harmonic and/or linear restraints on one or more variables.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the values the harmonic restraint acts upon

SLOPE.description: specifies that the restraint is linear and what the values of the force constants on each of the variables are

KAPPA.description: specifies that the restraint is harmonic and what the values of the force constants on each of the variables are

STRIDE.description: the frequency with which the forces due to the bias should be calculated

bias.description: the instantaneous value of the bias potential

force2.description: the instantaneous value of the squared force due to this bias potential

RESTRAINT.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  SLOPE - ( default=0.0 ) specifies that the restraint is linear and 
                          what the values of the force constants on each of the variables 
                          are 
                  KAPPA - ( default=0.0 ) specifies that the restraint is harmonic 
                          and what the values of the force constants on each of the 
                          variables are 
                     AT - the position of the restraint 
                    ARG - the values the harmonic restraint acts upon. You can use 
                          multiple instances of this keyword i.e. ARG1, ARG2, ARG3...

REWEIGHT_BIAS.description: Calculate weights for ensemble averages that negate the effect the bias has on the region of phase space explored

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

TEMP.description: the system temperature

ARG.description: the biases that must be taken into account when reweighting

value.description: the weight to use for this frame to negate the effect the bias

REWEIGHT_BIAS.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - ( default=*.bias ) the biases that must be taken into 
                          account when reweighting 
                   TEMP - the system temperature. This is not required if your MD 
                          code passes this quantity to PLUMED

REWEIGHT_METAD.description: Calculate the weights configurations should contribute to the histogram in a simulation in which a metadynamics bias acts upon the system.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

TEMP.description: the system temperature

ARG.description: the biases that must be taken into account when reweighting

value.description: the weight to use for this frame to negate the effect the metadynamics bias

REWEIGHT_METAD.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - ( default=*.rbias ) the biases that must be taken into 
                          account when reweighting 
                   TEMP - the system temperature. This is not required if your MD 
                          code passes this quantity to PLUMED

REWEIGHT_TEMP_PRESS.description: Calculate weights for ensemble averages at temperatures and/or pressures different than those used in your original simulation.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

TEMP.description: the system temperature

value.description: the weight to use for this frame to determine its contribution at a different temperature/pressure

REWEIGHT_TEMP_PRESS.help:
TEMP - the system temperature. This is not required if your MD 
                          code passes this quantity to PLUMED 
                 ENERGY - Energy 
                 VOLUME - Volume 
      REWEIGHT_PRESSURE - Reweighting pressure 
               PRESSURE - The system pressure 
          REWEIGHT_TEMP - Reweighting temperature

RMSD.description: Calculate the RMSD with respect to a reference structure.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

REFERENCE.description: a file in pdb format containing the reference structure and the atoms involved in the CV

TYPE.description: the manner in which RMSD alignment is performed

SQUARED.description: This should be setted if you want MSD instead of RMSD

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

DISPLACEMENT.description: Calculate the vector of displacements instead of the length of this vector

ARG.description: instead of using the REFERENCE option you can use this action to specify the labels of two actions that you are calculating the RMSD between

NUMBER.description: if there are multiple structures in the pdb file you can specify that you want the RMSD from a specific structure by specifying its place in the file here

disp.description: the vector of displacements for the atoms

dist.description: the RMSD distance the atoms have moved

value.description: the RMSD distance between the instaneous structure and the reference structure/s that were input

RMSD.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

              REFERENCE - a file in pdb format containing the reference structure and 
                          the atoms involved in the CV 
                   TYPE - ( default=SIMPLE ) the manner in which RMSD alignment is 
                          performed. Should be OPTIMAL or SIMPLE. 
                 NUMBER - ( default=0 ) if there are multiple structures in the pdb 
                          file you can specify that you want the RMSD from a specific 
                          structure by specifying its place in the file here. If NUMBER=0 then 
                          the RMSD from all structures are computed 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                SQUARED - ( default=off ) This should be setted if you want MSD 
                          instead of RMSD 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
           DISPLACEMENT - ( default=off ) Calculate the vector of displacements 
                          instead of the length of this vector 
                    ARG - instead of using the REFERENCE option you can use this 
                          action to specify the labels of two actions that you are 
                          calculating the RMSD between

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

REFERENCE.description: a file in pdb format containing the reference structure and the atoms involved in the CV

TYPE.description: the manner in which RMSD alignment is performed

SQUARED.description: This should be set if you want mean squared displacement instead of RMSD

value.description: the RMSD between the instantaneous structure and the reference structure that was input

RMSD_SCALAR.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

              REFERENCE - a file in pdb format containing the reference structure and 
                          the atoms involved in the CV. 
                   TYPE - ( default=SIMPLE ) the manner in which RMSD alignment is 
                          performed. Should be OPTIMAL or SIMPLE. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                SQUARED - ( default=off ) This should be set if you want mean squared 
                          displacement instead of RMSD

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of two actions that you are calculating the RMSD between

TYPE.description: the manner in which RMSD alignment is performed

ALIGN.description: the weights to use when aligning to the reference structure

DISPLACE.description: the weights to use when calculating the displacement from the reference structure

SQUARED.description: This should be set if you want mean squared displacement instead of RMSD

UNORMALIZED.description: by default the mean sequare deviation or root mean square deviation is calculated

DISPLACEMENT.description: Calculate the vector of displacements instead of the length of this vector

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

disp.description: the vector of displacements for the atoms

dist.description: the RMSD distance the atoms have moved

value.description: a vector containing the RMSD between the instantaneous structure and each of the reference structures that were input

RMSD_VECTOR.help:
The following arguments are compulsory: 

                    ARG - the labels of two actions that you are calculating the RMSD 
                          between 
                   TYPE - ( default=SIMPLE ) the manner in which RMSD alignment is 
                          performed. Should be OPTIMAL or SIMPLE. 
                  ALIGN - ( default=1.0 ) the weights to use when aligning to the 
                          reference structure 
               DISPLACE - ( default=1.0 ) the weights to use when calculating the 
                          displacement from the reference structure 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                SQUARED - ( default=off ) This should be set if you want mean squared 
                          displacement instead of RMSD 
            UNORMALIZED - ( default=off ) by default the mean sequare deviation or 
                          root mean square deviation is calculated. If this option is 
                          given no averaging is done 
           DISPLACEMENT - ( default=off ) Calculate the vector of displacements 
                          instead of the length of this vector 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

IS_SHORTCUT.description: hidden keyword to tell if actions are shortcuts so that example generator can provide expansions of shortcuts

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

SPECIES.description: this keyword is used for colvars such as coordination number

SPECIESA.description: this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination number

SPECIESB.description: this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination number

QUATERNIONS.description: the label of the action that computes the quaternions that should be used

KERNELFILE_DOPS.description: the file containing the list of kernel parameters

KERNELFILE_ROPS.description: the file containing the list of kernel parameters

value.description: the values of the ROPS order parameters

ROPS.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                SPECIES - this keyword is used for colvars such as coordination 
                          number. In that context it specifies that plumed should calculate 
                          one coordination number for each of the atoms specified. Each 
                          of these coordination numbers specifies how many of the other 
                          specified atoms are within a certain cutoff of the central atom. You 
                          can specify the atoms here as another multicolvar action or 
                          using a MultiColvarFilter or ActionVolume action. When you do so 
                          the quantity is calculated for those atoms specified in the 
                          previous multicolvar. This is useful if you would like to calculate 
                          the Steinhardt parameter for those atoms that have a 
                          coordination number more than four for example. For more information on 
                          how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
               SPECIESA - this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination 
                          number. In that context it species that plumed should calculate one 
                          coordination number for each of the atoms specified in SPECIESA. Each of 
                          these cooordination numbers specifies how many of the atoms 
                          specifies using SPECIESB is within the specified cutoff. As with the 
                          species keyword the input can also be specified using the label of 
                          another multicolvar 
               SPECIESB - this keyword is used for colvars such as the coordination 
                          number. It must appear with SPECIESA. For a full explanation see 
                          the documentation for that keyword 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

            QUATERNIONS - the label of the action that computes the quaternions that 
                          should be used 
        KERNELFILE_DOPS - the file containing the list of kernel parameters. We 
                          expect h, mu and sigma parameters for a 1D Gaussian kernel of the 
                          form h*exp(-(x-mu)^2/2sigma^2) 
        KERNELFILE_ROPS - the file containing the list of kernel parameters. We 
                          expect the normalization factor (height), concentration parameter 
                          (kappa), and 4 quaternion pieces of the mean for a bipolar watson 
                          distribution (mu_w,mu_i,mu_j,mu_k)): (h*exp(kappa*dot(q_mean,q))), where 
                          dot is the dot product 
                 CUTOFF - cutoff for the distance matrix

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

SERIAL.description: Perform the calculation in serial - for debug purpose

NLIST.description: Use a neighbour list to speed up the calculation

NL_CUTOFF.description: The cutoff for the neighbour list

NL_STRIDE.description: The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the neighbour list

METHYL_ATOM.description: the methyl carbon atom of the residue (i)

NH_ATOMS.description: the hydrogen atom of the NH group of the residue (i) and carbonyl oxygen of the preceding residue (i-1)

HEAVY_ATOMS.description: the heavy atoms to be included in the calculation

R_EFF.description: the effective distance, r_eff in the equation, given in nm

PREFACTOR_A.description: the prefactor, a in the equation

EXPONENT_B.description: the exponent, b in the equation

OFFSET_C.description: the offset, c in the equation

R_SHIFT.description: shift all distances by given amount

value.description: the value of the CV

S2CM.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

            METHYL_ATOM - the methyl carbon atom of the residue (i). For more 
                          information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
               NH_ATOMS - the hydrogen atom of the NH group of the residue (i) and 
                          carbonyl oxygen of the preceding residue (i-1). For more information 
                          on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 
            HEAVY_ATOMS - the heavy atoms to be included in the calculation. For more 
                          information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                  R_EFF - the effective distance, r_eff in the equation, given in nm. 
            PREFACTOR_A - the prefactor, a in the equation 
             EXPONENT_B - the exponent, b in the equation 
               OFFSET_C - the offset, c in the equation 
                    N_I - n_i in the equation 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
                  NLIST - ( default=off ) Use a neighbour list to speed up the 
                          calculation 
              NL_CUTOFF - The cutoff for the neighbour list 
              NL_STRIDE - The frequency with which we are updating the atoms in the 
                          neighbour list 
                R_SHIFT - shift all distances by given amount

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the values from which the function is calculated

REWEIGHT.description: simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy

AVERAGING.description: Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean

LIKELIHOOD.description: the likelihood for the GENERIC metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN

DFTILDE.description: fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve ftilde

SCALEDATA.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling factor common to all values and replicas

SCALE0.description: initial value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MIN.description: minimum value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MAX.description: maximum value of the scaling factor

DSCALE.description: maximum MC move of the scaling factor

ADDOFFSET.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset common to all values and replicas

DOFFSET.description: maximum MC move of the offset

REGRES_ZERO.description: stride for regression with zero offset

SIGMA0.description: initial value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MIN.description: minimum value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MAX.description: maximum value of the uncertainty parameter

DSIGMA.description: maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter

OPTSIGMAMEAN.description: Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma mean, or to estimate it on the fly

SIGMA_MEAN0.description: starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate

SIGMA_MAX_STEPS.description: Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the SIGMA_MAX value is used

TEMP.description: the system temperature - this is only needed if code doesn't pass the temperature to plumed

STATUS_FILE.description: write a file with all the data useful for restart/continuation of Metainference

FMT.description: specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the number of digits in regtests)

WRITE_STRIDE.description: write the status to a file every N steps, this can be used for restart/continuation

NSELECT.description: range of values for selector [0, N-1]

NOPBC.description: Ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

SERIAL.description: Perform the calculation in serial - for debug purpose

DEVICEID.description: Identifier of the GPU to be used

GPU.description: Calculate SAXS using ARRAYFIRE on an accelerator device

ABSOLUTE.description: Absolute intensity: the intensities for each q-value are not normalised for the intensity at q=0

ATOMISTIC.description: Calculate SAXS for an atomistic model

MARTINI.description: Calculate SAXS for a Martini model

ONEBEAD.description: calculate SAXS for a single bead model

TEMPLATE.description: A PDB file is required for ONEBEAD mapping

ATOMS.description: The atoms to be included in the calculation, e

QVALUE.description: Selected scattering lengths in inverse angstroms are given as QVALUE1, QVALUE2,

PARAMETERS.description: Used parameter Keywords like PARAMETERS1, PARAMETERS2

PARAMETERSFILE.description: Read the PARAMETERS from a file

SOLVDENS.description: Density of the solvent to be used for the correction of atomistic form factors

SOLVATION_CORRECTION.description: Solvation layer electron density correction (ONEBEAD only)

SASA_CUTOFF.description: SASA value to consider a residue as exposed to the solvent (ONEBEAD only)

EXPINT.description: Add an experimental value for each q value

SIGMARES.description: Variance of Gaussian distribution describing the deviation in the scattering angle for each q value

N.description: Number of points in the resolution function integral

SOLVATION_STRIDE.description: Number of steps between every new residues solvation estimation via LCPO (ONEBEAD only)

SCALE_EXPINT.description: Scaling value for experimental data normalization

acceptFT.description: MC acceptance for general metainference f tilde value

biasDer.description: derivatives with respect to the bias

SANS.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - The atoms to be included in the calculation, e.g. the whole 
                          protein. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see 
                          ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              NOISETYPE - ( default=MGAUSS ) functional form of the noise 
                          (GAUSS,MGAUSS,OUTLIERS,MOUTLIERS,GENERIC) 
             LIKELIHOOD - ( default=GAUSS ) the likelihood for the GENERIC 
                          metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN 
                DFTILDE - ( default=0.1 ) fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve 
                          ftilde 
                 SCALE0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the scaling factor 
            SCALE_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                OFFSET0 - ( default=0.0 ) initial value of the offset 
           OFFSET_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                 SIGMA0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MIN - ( default=0.0 ) minimum value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MAX - ( default=10. ) maximum value of the uncertainty parameter 
           OPTSIGMAMEAN - ( default=NONE ) Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma 
                          mean, or to estimate it on the fly 
           WRITE_STRIDE - ( default=10000 ) write the status to a file every N steps, 
                          this can be used for restart/continuation 
               DEVICEID - ( default=-1 ) Identifier of the GPU to be used 
               TEMPLATE - ( default=template.pdb ) A PDB file is required for ONEBEAD 
                          mapping 
            DEUTER_CONC - ( default=0. ) Fraction of deuterated solvent 
               SOLVDENS - ( default=0.334 ) Density of the solvent to be used for the 
                          correction of atomistic form factors 
   SOLVATION_CORRECTION - ( default=0.0 ) Solvation layer electron density correction 
                          (ONEBEAD only) 
            SASA_CUTOFF - ( default=1.0 ) SASA value to consider a residue as exposed 
                          to the solvent (ONEBEAD only) 
                      N - ( default=10 ) Number of points in the resolution function 
                          integral 
       SOLVATION_STRIDE - ( default=10 ) Number of steps between every new residues 
                          solvation estimation via LCPO (ONEBEAD only) 
           SCALE_EXPINT - ( default=1.0 ) Scaling value for experimental data 
                          normalization 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                DOSCORE - ( default=off ) activate metainference 
             NOENSEMBLE - ( default=off ) don't perform any replica-averaging 
               REWEIGHT - ( default=off ) simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy 
              SCALEDATA - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling 
                          factor common to all values and replicas 
              ADDOFFSET - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset 
                          common to all values and replicas 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) Ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
                    GPU - ( default=off ) Calculate SAXS using ARRAYFIRE on an 
                          accelerator device 
               ABSOLUTE - ( default=off ) Absolute intensity: the intensities for 
                          each q-value are not normalised for the intensity at q=0. 
              ATOMISTIC - ( default=off ) Calculate SAXS for an atomistic model 
                MARTINI - ( default=off ) Calculate SAXS for a Martini model 
                ONEBEAD - ( default=off ) calculate SAXS for a single bead model 
                    ARG - the labels of the values from which the function is 
                          calculated 
              AVERAGING - Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean 
              SCALE_MIN - minimum value of the scaling factor 
              SCALE_MAX - maximum value of the scaling factor 
                 DSCALE - maximum MC move of the scaling factor 
             OFFSET_MIN - minimum value of the offset 
             OFFSET_MAX - maximum value of the offset 
                DOFFSET - maximum MC move of the offset 
            REGRES_ZERO - stride for regression with zero offset 
                 DSIGMA - maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter 
            SIGMA_MEAN0 - starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate 
        SIGMA_MAX_STEPS - Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the 
                          SIGMA_MAX value is used 
                   TEMP - the system temperature - this is only needed if code 
                          doesn't pass the temperature to plumed 
               MC_STEPS - number of MC steps 
           MC_CHUNKSIZE - MC chunksize 
            STATUS_FILE - write a file with all the data useful for 
                          restart/continuation of Metainference 
                    FMT - specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the 
                          number of digits in regtests) 
               SELECTOR - name of selector 
                NSELECT - range of values for selector [0, N-1] 
                RESTART - allows per-action setting of restart (YES/NO/AUTO) 
                 QVALUE - Selected scattering lengths in inverse angstroms are given 
                          as QVALUE1, QVALUE2, .... You can use multiple instances of 
                          this keyword i.e. QVALUE1, QVALUE2, QVALUE3... 
             PARAMETERS - Used parameter Keywords like PARAMETERS1, PARAMETERS2. 
         PARAMETERSFILE - Read the PARAMETERS from a file 
                 EXPINT - Add an experimental value for each q value. You can use 
                          multiple instances of this keyword i.e. EXPINT1, EXPINT2, EXPINT3... 
               SIGMARES - Variance of Gaussian distribution describing the deviation 
                          in the scattering angle for each q value. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. SIGMARES1, SIGMARES2, SIGMARES3...

SASA_HASEL.description: Calculates the solvent accessible surface area (SASA) of a protein molecule, or other properties related to it.

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

ATOMS.description: the group of atoms that you are calculating the SASA for

TYPE.description: The type of calculation you want to perform

NL_STRIDE.description: The frequency with which the neighbor list for the calculation of SASA is updated

DELTAGFILE.description: a file containing the free energy of transfer values for backbone and sidechains atoms

value.description: the solvent accessible surface area (SASA) of the molecule

SASA_HASEL.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - the group of atoms that you are calculating the SASA for. 
                          For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef 
                          Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

                   TYPE - ( default=TOTAL ) The type of calculation you want to 
                          perform. Can be TOTAL or TRANSFER 
              NL_STRIDE - The frequency with which the neighbor list for the 
                          calculation of SASA is updated. 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
             DELTAGFILE - a file containing the free energy of transfer values for 
                          backbone and sidechains atoms. Necessary only if TYPE = TRANSFER. A 
                          Python script for the computation of free energy of transfer 
                          values to describe the effect of osmolyte concentration, 
                          temperature and pressure is freely available at 
                          https://github.com/andrea-arsiccio/DeltaG-calculation. The script automatically outputs a DeltaG.dat file 
                          compatible with this SASA module. If TYPE = TRANSFER and no DELTAGFILE 
                          is provided, the free energy values are those describing the 
                          effect of temperature, and are computed using the temperature 
                          value passed by the MD engine 
               APPROACH - either approach 2 or 3. Necessary only if TYPE = TRANSFER 
                          and no DELTAGFILE is provided. If TYPE = TRANSFER and no 
                          DELTAGFILE is provided, the free energy values are those describing 
                          the effect of temperature, and the program must know if 
                          approach 2 or 3 (as described in Arsiccio and Shea, Protein Cold 
                          Denaturation in Implicit Solvent Simulations: A Transfer Free Energy 
                          Approach, J. Phys. Chem. B, 2021) needs to be used to compute them

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES.description: calculate the derivatives for these quantities numerically

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

ARG.description: the labels of the values from which the function is calculated

REWEIGHT.description: simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy

AVERAGING.description: Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean

LIKELIHOOD.description: the likelihood for the GENERIC metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN

DFTILDE.description: fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve ftilde

SCALEDATA.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling factor common to all values and replicas

SCALE0.description: initial value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MIN.description: minimum value of the scaling factor

SCALE_MAX.description: maximum value of the scaling factor

DSCALE.description: maximum MC move of the scaling factor

ADDOFFSET.description: Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset common to all values and replicas

DOFFSET.description: maximum MC move of the offset

REGRES_ZERO.description: stride for regression with zero offset

SIGMA0.description: initial value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MIN.description: minimum value of the uncertainty parameter

SIGMA_MAX.description: maximum value of the uncertainty parameter

DSIGMA.description: maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter

OPTSIGMAMEAN.description: Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma mean, or to estimate it on the fly

SIGMA_MEAN0.description: starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate

SIGMA_MAX_STEPS.description: Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the SIGMA_MAX value is used

TEMP.description: the system temperature - this is only needed if code doesn't pass the temperature to plumed

STATUS_FILE.description: write a file with all the data useful for restart/continuation of Metainference

FMT.description: specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the number of digits in regtests)

WRITE_STRIDE.description: write the status to a file every N steps, this can be used for restart/continuation

NSELECT.description: range of values for selector [0, N-1]

NOPBC.description: Ignore the periodic boundary conditions when calculating distances

SERIAL.description: Perform the calculation in serial - for debug purpose

DEVICEID.description: Identifier of the GPU to be used

GPU.description: Calculate SAXS using ARRAYFIRE on an accelerator device

ABSOLUTE.description: Absolute intensity: the intensities for each q-value are not normalised for the intensity at q=0

ATOMISTIC.description: Calculate SAXS for an atomistic model

MARTINI.description: Calculate SAXS for a Martini model

ONEBEAD.description: calculate SAXS for a single bead model

TEMPLATE.description: A PDB file is required for ONEBEAD mapping

QVALUE.description: Selected scattering lengths in inverse angstroms are given as QVALUE1, QVALUE2,

PARAMETERS.description: Used parameter Keywords like PARAMETERS1, PARAMETERS2

PARAMETERSFILE.description: Read the PARAMETERS from a file

SASA_CUTOFF.description: SASA value to consider a residue as exposed to the solvent (ONEBEAD only)

SIGMARES.description: Variance of Gaussian distribution describing the deviation in the scattering angle for each q value

N.description: Number of points in the resolution function integral

SOLVATION_STRIDE.description: Number of steps between every new residues solvation estimation via LCPO (ONEBEAD only)

acceptFT.description: MC acceptance for general metainference f tilde value

biasDer.description: derivatives with respect to the bias

SAXS.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

                  ATOMS - The atoms to be included in the calculation, e.g. the whole 
                          protein. For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see 
                          ef Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

              NOISETYPE - ( default=MGAUSS ) functional form of the noise 
                          (GAUSS,MGAUSS,OUTLIERS,MOUTLIERS,GENERIC) 
             LIKELIHOOD - ( default=GAUSS ) the likelihood for the GENERIC 
                          metainference model, GAUSS or LOGN 
                DFTILDE - ( default=0.1 ) fraction of sigma_mean used to evolve 
                          ftilde 
                 SCALE0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the scaling factor 
            SCALE_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                OFFSET0 - ( default=0.0 ) initial value of the offset 
           OFFSET_PRIOR - ( default=FLAT ) either FLAT or GAUSSIAN 
                 SIGMA0 - ( default=1.0 ) initial value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MIN - ( default=0.0 ) minimum value of the uncertainty parameter 
              SIGMA_MAX - ( default=10. ) maximum value of the uncertainty parameter 
           OPTSIGMAMEAN - ( default=NONE ) Set to NONE/SEM to manually set sigma 
                          mean, or to estimate it on the fly 
           WRITE_STRIDE - ( default=10000 ) write the status to a file every N steps, 
                          this can be used for restart/continuation 
               DEVICEID - ( default=-1 ) Identifier of the GPU to be used 
               TEMPLATE - ( default=template.pdb ) A PDB file is required for ONEBEAD 
                          mapping 
            DEUTER_CONC - ( default=0. ) Fraction of deuterated solvent 
               SOLVDENS - ( default=0.334 ) Density of the solvent to be used for the 
                          correction of atomistic form factors 
   SOLVATION_CORRECTION - ( default=0.0 ) Solvation layer electron density correction 
                          (ONEBEAD only) 
            SASA_CUTOFF - ( default=1.0 ) SASA value to consider a residue as exposed 
                          to the solvent (ONEBEAD only) 
                      N - ( default=10 ) Number of points in the resolution function 
                          integral 
       SOLVATION_STRIDE - ( default=10 ) Number of steps between every new residues 
                          solvation estimation via LCPO (ONEBEAD only) 
           SCALE_EXPINT - ( default=1.0 ) Scaling value for experimental data 
                          normalization 

In addition you may use the following options: 

  NUMERICAL_DERIVATIVES - ( default=off ) calculate the derivatives for these 
                          quantities numerically 
                DOSCORE - ( default=off ) activate metainference 
             NOENSEMBLE - ( default=off ) don't perform any replica-averaging 
               REWEIGHT - ( default=off ) simple REWEIGHT using the ARG as energy 
              SCALEDATA - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample a scaling 
                          factor common to all values and replicas 
              ADDOFFSET - ( default=off ) Set to TRUE if you want to sample an offset 
                          common to all values and replicas 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) Ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                          when calculating distances 
                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) Perform the calculation in serial - for 
                          debug purpose 
                    GPU - ( default=off ) Calculate SAXS using ARRAYFIRE on an 
                          accelerator device 
               ABSOLUTE - ( default=off ) Absolute intensity: the intensities for 
                          each q-value are not normalised for the intensity at q=0. 
              ATOMISTIC - ( default=off ) Calculate SAXS for an atomistic model 
                MARTINI - ( default=off ) Calculate SAXS for a Martini model 
                ONEBEAD - ( default=off ) calculate SAXS for a single bead model 
                    ARG - the labels of the values from which the function is 
                          calculated 
              AVERAGING - Stride for calculation of averaged weights and sigma_mean 
              SCALE_MIN - minimum value of the scaling factor 
              SCALE_MAX - maximum value of the scaling factor 
                 DSCALE - maximum MC move of the scaling factor 
             OFFSET_MIN - minimum value of the offset 
             OFFSET_MAX - maximum value of the offset 
                DOFFSET - maximum MC move of the offset 
            REGRES_ZERO - stride for regression with zero offset 
                 DSIGMA - maximum MC move of the uncertainty parameter 
            SIGMA_MEAN0 - starting value for the uncertainty in the mean estimate 
        SIGMA_MAX_STEPS - Number of steps used to optimise SIGMA_MAX, before that the 
                          SIGMA_MAX value is used 
                   TEMP - the system temperature - this is only needed if code 
                          doesn't pass the temperature to plumed 
               MC_STEPS - number of MC steps 
           MC_CHUNKSIZE - MC chunksize 
            STATUS_FILE - write a file with all the data useful for 
                          restart/continuation of Metainference 
                    FMT - specify format for HILLS files (useful for decrease the 
                          number of digits in regtests) 
               SELECTOR - name of selector 
                NSELECT - range of values for selector [0, N-1] 
                RESTART - allows per-action setting of restart (YES/NO/AUTO) 
                 QVALUE - Selected scattering lengths in inverse angstroms are given 
                          as QVALUE1, QVALUE2, .... You can use multiple instances of 
                          this keyword i.e. QVALUE1, QVALUE2, QVALUE3... 
             PARAMETERS - Used parameter Keywords like PARAMETERS1, PARAMETERS2. 
         PARAMETERSFILE - Read the PARAMETERS from a file 
                 EXPINT - Add an experimental value for each q value. You can use 
                          multiple instances of this keyword i.e. EXPINT1, EXPINT2, EXPINT3... 
               SIGMARES - Variance of Gaussian distribution describing the deviation 
                          in the scattering angle for each q value. You can use multiple 
                          instances of this keyword i.e. SIGMARES1, SIGMARES2, SIGMARES3...

SECONDARY_STRUCTURE_DRMSD.description: Calclulate the DRMSD between segments of a protein and a reference structure of interest

LABEL.description: a label for the action so that its output can be referenced in the input to other actions

HAS_VALUES.description: this is used in json output to determine those actions that have values

USEGPU.description: run this calculation on the GPU

NOPBC.description: ignore the periodic boundary conditions

MASK.description: a vector which is used to determine which elements of the secondary structure variable should be computed

RESIDUES.description: this command is used to specify the set of residues that could conceivably form part of the secondary structure

ATOMS.description: this is the full list of atoms that we are investigating

SEGMENT.description: this is the lists of atoms in the segment that are being considered

BONDLENGTH.description: the length to use for bonds

LESS_THAN.description: calculate the number of a residue segments that are within a certain target distance of this secondary structure type

R_0.description: The r_0 parameter of the switching function

D_0.description: The d_0 parameter of the switching function

NN.description: The n parameter of the switching function

MM.description: The m parameter of the switching function

ALIGN_STRANDS.description: ensure that the two halves of a beta sheet are not broken by the periodic boundaries before doing alignment

struct.description: the vectors containing the rmsd distances between the residues and each of the reference structures

lessthan.description: the number blocks of residues that have an RMSD from the secondary structure that is less than the threshold

SECONDARY_STRUCTURE_DRMSD.help:
The input trajectory can be in any of the following formats: 

               RESIDUES - this command is used to specify the set of residues that 
                          could conceivably form part of the secondary structure. It is 
                          possible to use residues numbers as the various chains and residues 
                          should have been identified else using an instance of the ef 
                          MOLINFO action. If you wish to use all the residues from all the 
                          chains in your system you can do so by specifying all. 
                          Alternatively, if you wish to use a subset of the residues you can specify 
                          the particular residues you are interested in as a list of 
                          numbers. Please be aware that to form secondary structure elements 
                          your chain must contain at least N residues, where N is 
                          dependent on the particular secondary structure you are interested 
                          in. As such if you define portions of the chain with fewer than 
                          N residues the code will crash. 
                  ATOMS - this is the full list of atoms that we are investigating. 
                          For more information on how to specify lists of atoms see ef 
                          Group 

The following arguments are compulsory: 

             BONDLENGTH - ( default=0.17 ) the length to use for bonds 
                    D_0 - ( default=0.0 ) The d_0 parameter of the switching function 
                     NN - ( default=8 ) The n parameter of the switching function 
                     MM - ( default=12 ) The m parameter of the switching function 

In addition you may use the following options: 

                 SERIAL - ( default=off ) do the calculation in serial. Do not 
                          parallelize 
                 USEGPU - ( default=off ) run this calculation on the GPU 
                  NOPBC - ( default=off ) ignore the periodic boundary conditions 
                VERBOSE - ( default=off ) write a more detailed output 
          ALIGN_STRANDS - ( default=off ) ensure that the two halves of a beta sheet 
                          are not broken by the periodic boundaries before doing 
                          alignment 
                   MASK - a vector which is used to determine which elements of the 
                          secondary structure variable should be computed 
                SEGMENT - this is the lists of atoms in the segment that are being 
                          considered. You can use multiple instances of this keyword i.e. 
                          SEGMENT1, SEGMENT2, SEGMENT3... 
              STRUCTURE - the reference structure. You can use multiple instances of 
                          this keyword i.e. STRUCTURE1, STRUCTURE2, STRUCTURE3... 
              LESS_THAN - calculate the number of a residue segments that are within 
                          a certain target distance of this secondary structure type. 
                    R_0 - The r_0 parameter of the switching function.
